Sir,

I beg to enclose a letter from Constable Francis re Six River School. I had no idea that this school was closed. The teacher did not notify me that she was closing the school. I would recommend that the Dept notify Miss T. Trotter. I am sure that the school will not be reopened at present.

Yours obedient servant,

M.R. Brown
Agent.

Ottawa, May 23, 1918.

Sir,

I have to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 16th instant enclosing a communication from Miss Trottier, teacher of the Pic School, and also of your letter of the 20th instant enclosing a communication from Constable Twance in regard to this school.

In reply I beg to say that if Miss Trottier is still at Heron Bay the Department considers that she should keep the school open until the end of June, next, as it is not necessary to heat the building now. You will be good enough to inform her, however, that the school will not be re-opened after the summer holidays.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLEAN

Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

W. R. Brown, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Port Arthur, Ont.
Mr. W.R. Brown,
Port Arthur,
Ont.

Dear Mr. Brown,

Received your letter saying
Povance had informed you that the
school had been closed for over a month.
I wonder where he received all his
information as he and his family
have been away since the middle of
March. Chief Michano said to close
school on account of having no wood
and to put in that month later as
the children would be here then, where
now I would have had only three pupils
at the most and when I mentioned
it to Povance the other day he also
agreed that it would be better. They
tell me one thing and go and write
you another. I have reopened school
and the cold does not affect me if
the children can put up with it.
I can and from now on I will report
all to you! They have stolen money.
from me and broken open my trunk
and I never troubled you about that
but friends here in H/Bay has told
St. Belanger about it so I suppose that
won't happen again. I have lost three
weeks, but I don't mind as long as
I can make it up while the children
are here. From now on no matter
what they say or what kind of a
day it is I will be at my desk
and if they don't send their children
I will report to you. Chief Michano
has given me to understand more
than once that I was to take orders
from him for the school, but its the
last I'll take from men who have
no more word than they, and
about my board money I asked
Michano when I received my cheque
in March if he wanted his money
then, and he had just got back from
hunting so had made quite a lot on his furs and he said "No better pay me in June when I am broke?" Now Mr Brown those are the very words he spoke. And then I paid Mr Bege for I was bashing myself and have been only boarding a little while then I sent home the remainder and then when I had sent away my money he had a case sent him C.C.D. and it was in the express and then he came asking me for it money which of course I had not and I suppose he thought I did not want to give it to him just then but it was not my fault he should have taken it when I offered it to him hoping to receive a reply by Friday and let me know all you wish me to do.

I remain, Yours truly,

Celine Lottier
Sir,

Re Pic River School:

I beg to enclose a letter from Miss Bottler which will explain itself.

She certainly made a mistake in not informing me that the school was closed but probably her intentions were alright.

In a previous letter she asked for an advance of $50.00 so that she could buy some money to Chief Michans for board.

Your obedient servant,

W.R. Brown
Agent

Ottawa, May 30, 1918.

Sir,

I have to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 23rd instant enclosing a communication from Miss Trottier in regard to the Pic School.

In reply I beg to refer you to official letter of the 23rd instant, in which you were informed that the Department considers that Miss Trottier should keep this school open until the end of June, next, but that it will not be re-opened after the summer holidays. If Miss Trottier desires, she may keep the school open in July to make up the days she lost while the school was closed.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

Indian Agent,

Heron Bay Out
June 19th 1918

Mr. W. Brown
Post-Office

Dear Mr. Brown,

Could you kindly send me a couple of report forms by return of mail and also tell me if it would be convenient to the Department to teach during the month of July as last year and then put in the lost time of May in August.

An early reply will greatly oblige.

Yours truly,
Celina Scottie

P.S. The attendance has been very good this while back I have 23 on roll. Kindly let me know what time you intend visiting the Reserve.

C.T.
Sir,

I beg to enclose a letter from Miss Trotter of the Pias River School. Kindly advise if she should be allowed to teach until end of July and then put in her last time as she desires.

Your obedient servant,

W.R. Brown
Agent

Ottawa, June 25, 1918.

Sir,

I have to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 21st instant enclosing a communication from Miss Trottier, teacher of the Pic School, in which she asks if it would be convenient to the Department for her to teach during the month of July, as last year, and then put in the time lost in May in August.

In reply I beg to say that, as you were informed in official letter of the 30th ultimo, Miss Trottier may keep the school open in July to make up the days she lost while the school was closed during the month of May. When the lost time has been made up the school should be closed. As you have already been advised, the school will not be re-opened after the summer holidays.

Your obedient servant,

W. R. Brown, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Fort Arthur, Ont.

I am not in favor of opening schools at Red Rock or Pic River until we have a guaranteed attendance. These Indians generally spend most of their time off the Reserves and take the school children with them.
September 13, 1916.

Sir,

I have to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 10th instant in regard to the Red Rock, Pic River and Mission Bay schools.

In reply I beg to say that, in view of your remarks that you are not in favour of opening schools at Red Rock or Pic River until there is a guaranteed attendance, these schools may remain closed for the present. It will not be necessary, therefore, for you to take any action in regard to repairs to the Red Rock school building.

As the Red Rock school will not be re-opened, Mrs. McLaren, who has been teaching there, may be placed in charge of the Mission Bay school and she will be allowed a salary at the rate of $400.00 per annum. Kindly advise the Department of the date on which she takes up her duties at this school.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

Assistant Deputy and Secretary,

W. R. Brown, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Fort Arthur, Ont.
Sir,

The Indians are all back on the Six Reserve again and it might be advisable to open the school for the next five months at least. It is very difficult to secure attendance here during the winter as the children go to the woods with their parents.

Mrs. Davies McLean could be secured at $60 per month to take charge of this school while the attendance warrants its being kept open.

Kindly advise if Mrs. McLean may be employed provided that I have the assurance of Chief Michans that the children will all attend.

Yours obedient servant,

W.R. Brown
Agent

The Secretary
Dept. of Indian Affairs
Ottawa.
Ottawa, June 25, 1919.

Sir,

I have to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 21st instant, in which you state that all the Indians are back on the Pic Reserve and it might be advisable to open the school for the next five months and that Mrs. Xavier McLaren could be secured at $60.00 a month to take charge of this school while the attendance warrants its being kept open.

In reply I beg to say that Mrs. McLaren may be placed in charge of this school and she will be allowed $60.00 a month for her services. She should re-open the school at once and it should be kept open as long as the attendance warrants it. Kindly advise the Department of the date on which she takes up her duties.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

W. R. Brown, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Fort Arthur, Ont.
Extract from letter from Agent Brown dated August 1, 1919. Original on 307515/1

The Indians at Pic River Reserve decided that they did not want a teacher for the summer months as the berry season has just opened and by the time they finish picking berries they will all leave for their hunting grounds and take the children with them.
Ottawa, August 7, 1919.

Sir,

I have to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 1st instant informing the Department that Mrs. Xavier McLaren has applied for the position of teacher of the Mission Bay Indian Day School and recommending that she be engaged.

In reply I beg to say that the Department will consent to the appointment of Mrs. McLaren as teacher of this school, to begin duties on or about the first of September, next, on the re-opening of the school after the summer holidays. She will be paid a salary at the rate of $500.00 per annum.

It is noted that the Pic School, to which Mrs. McLaren was appointed for the summer months, will not be re-opened, as the Indians will be away from the reserve.

You will be good enough to inform Mrs. McLaren of her appointment, and inform the Department of the date on which she begins duties.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean
Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

W. R. Brown, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Port Arthur, Ont.

Gentlemen,

I wish to apply for the Indian school at Severn Bay.

I am hoping to hear from you soon.

Lawrence Cutter.

Sir:

I have to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 7th instant, applying for the position as teacher of the Indian school at Pic River.

In reply I beg to say that it is not the intention of the Department to re-open this school at the present time. We have no other school available to which you could be assigned.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean,
Asst. Deputy & Secretary.

Lawrence Peltier, Esq.,
Outler,

Port Arthur,
8th September 1923.

To the Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.

Sir:

The Indians in the district of Heron Bay and
of Mobert are very anxious to have educational facilities
for their children, and are willing to do all in their
power to help in establishing teachers.

x x x x

In the case of Heron Bay, the School-house
has been closed for some years, and it is estimated that
the cost of renovating this would be about $100.00

Will you kindly let me know if anything can
be done in this matter.

Your obedient servant,

(Sgd.) J.G. Burk
Indian Agent.
OTTAWA, Sept. 19, 1923.

Sir:

I have to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 8th instant, informing the Department that the Indians at Heron Bay (Pic River) and Moberl are desirous of having the day schools at both these points re-opened, in order that educational facilities may be provided for their children.

In reply I beg to say that when these schools were in operation in the past the work accomplished was, owing to the poor attendance, very unsatisfactory. We note that there is no school building at Moberl, and the conducting of school in an Indian residence would be unsatisfactory. We are not prepared at the present time to authorize the re-opening of these two schools.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Acting Asst. Deputy & Secretary.

J. G. Burk, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Port Arthur,
Ont.
Dear Sir,

Would it not be possible to have a school opened at Pic River Reserve? There are lots of children, but now I don't dare to ask for that school because the Indians were not willing to stay on the reserve during the hunting season, but now they promise to stay for the school time. A new building is necessary, the old one is all rotten, and too small an one for such a number of children.

I am writing directly to you so that it will not delay much for the construction. I would propose to have it made by some good carpenters, not by the Indians, to have a good building, and not a hut; to have a building as we see on Manitoulin Island, that tells in favor of you.

Dear Sir,

Should I profit by the occasion to dare to ask you for a house should I say, for my school at the mission at Saginaw, I am in debt again for the separation of last summer and now I should put a new floor and have the room made larger. As you know the lumber is very dear and so the carpenters, the Indians seem to be interested in the school as they try to send their children—

I am leaving for Fort Hope next week and will not be back till July.

Thanking you in advance

Ottawa, May 28th, 1924.

Rev. Sir:

I have to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 24th instant, in which you request that the Pic River Indian Day School be re-opened and that a new school building be erected.

In reply I beg to say that the Department has no funds available this fiscal year for the purpose of erecting a building. When this school was in operation in the past the work accomplished was, owing to the poor attendance, very unsatisfactory. Unless we are definitely assured that the Indian children would remain on the reserve for the greater portion of each year, it would be useless to re-open this school. It will, therefore, not be possible to favourably consider your request at the present time.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean,
Asst. Deputy & Secretary.

Re: Chas. Belanger, S.J.,
Nepigon,
Ont.
MEMORANDUM:

February 15th, 1926.

Mr. Burk, Indian Agent, Port Arthur, has discussed the day school situation at Pic, Sand Point, Mobert and Gull Bay. At one time or another schools were in operation at all four of these Reserves. Mr. Burk is of the opinion that there will be an agitation for the reopening of these schools. He considers it advisable to experiment with one Reserve, and suggests Pic as the most promising. A summer school might be granted here, as there is an old schoolhouse. Desks would be required and, if the work was continued during the winter months, arrangements would have to be made to put the building in good shape.

I have not suggested to Mr. Burk that he advocate commencing a school at Pic, but if the demand is strong enough we might favourably consider the matter.
Port Arthur, Ontario

April 29th, 1926.

Sir,

Referring to our conversation of Feb 18th last regarding the re-opening of the Day school on the Pic Reserve, I beg to advise that I have made an inspection of the old log school-house on the Reserve and find that it is possible to be used as a temporary summer school and I would suggest re-opening it as such, until such times as the Department feel assured of the need of a permanent school. The cost of the necessary repairs at present time on the above mentioned school would be approximately about $100 or $150.00.

Whereas the old desks are beyond repair, it would be necessary that new ones be furnished, to accommodate from 30 to 35 pupils.

Your obedient servant,

Indian Agent.

Russell T. Ferrier, Esq.,
Supt. of Indian Education,
Ottawa., Ont.

Ottawa, May 3rd, 1926.

Sir:

I have your letter of the 29th ultimo, relative to the reopening of a summer school on the Pic Reserve, and stating the condition of the present school building and the repairs that would be required to place it in a satisfactory condition.

In this connection I beg to say that the funds at our disposal this year are limited, and, unless there is urgent need for the opening of this school, the Department would not be prepared to provide the funds required in fitting up the building, supplying new desks and in the payment of a teacher's salary. However, before giving a definite decision, I should be pleased to have a further report from you as to whether you consider it urgent that a school be opened this coming summer or not, or whether it could not stand over until the following year.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean,
Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

J. G. Burk, Esq.,
Indian Agent,

Referring to your file No.9-7-1 and in reply to your letter of the 3rd instant, relative to the re-opening of the Pic Reserve summer school, I beg to state that I am of the opinion that the matter be held in abeyance until next year.

Ottawa, December 15, 1926.

Reverend Sir:

Rev. Father Jos. Guy, O.M.I., has left your letter of the 8th instant with the Department. I have been in correspondence with Mr. Indian Agent Burk for some time, in connection with the re-opening of the Pic Indian Day School. We have practically decided to give it a trial as a summer school only. The present building could be utilized with but minor repairs. The school might be conducted from May first to September 30th. Please let me know what you think of this arrangement.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean,
Asst. Deputy & Secretary.

Sir,

With further reference to your letter, file number 9-7-1, dated May 3rd, 1926, and my reply of the 18th, file number 210-2-6, regarding the opening of a school on the Pic Reserve, I beg to advise that I have just received another petition signed by sixty members of the Pic Band urging the Department to reopen a day school on this Reserve.

I have been studying this matter closely, and find that the majority of the children on this Reserve were not taken away hunting this winter with their fathers, but were left on the Reserve with their mothers.

Most of the parents refuse to send their children away from home to a boarding school. This means that the children receive no education.

As the Indians of this Reserve are gradually abandoning the Indian mode of life and taking up farming seriously, the children will not be taken away from the Reserve as in former years. Consequently the Indians are most anxious to have a permanent school established on their Reserve, and have been making frequent enquiries regarding this matter. I would strongly recommend that a school be opened on this Reserve at once.

The old school building which has not been used for years is in very poor repair, but could be fixed up temporarily.

No doubt if this school was reopened for the summer months we could ascertain by the attendance if it would be advisable to build a permanent school on this Reserve.

An early reply will be appreciated.

Your obedient servant,

J. G. Burk,
Indian Agent.

J. D. McLean, Esq.,
Asst. Deputy & Secretary,
Dept. of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.
Ottawa, May 3rd, 1927.

Sir:

I have your letter of the 27th ultimo, relative to the opening of a school for the coming summer months on the Pic Reserve. As the Indians are anxious that this school be reopened, you may arrange to have the old school building fitted up temporarily to carry on the work. No unnecessary expense should be incurred. The Department will leave this matter in your hands to complete arrangements for the carrying on of the classroom work in this old building.

Relative to the engagement of a teacher, I shall be pleased if you will take this matter up with the Rev. Joseph Couture, Mipigon, who is interested in the establishment of a school at this point and the nomination of the services of a teacher who would be suitable to carry on the work. The salary allowed would depend on the qualifications which the teacher obtained possesses. You have not stated whether living accommodation can be obtained by a teacher, but it is hoped that there will be no difficulty in doing so for the brief period the school will be in operation. The Department would like, if possible, to have work commence at this point by the 1st of June, next.

I shall be pleased to hear at an early date as to the arrangements you have made for the carrying on of the classroom work, also what accommodation can be provided for a teacher, and full particulars regarding the name, qualifications and experience of the teacher nominated by you for this summer school. Please give this matter your prompt attention.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Acting Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

J. G. Burk, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Port Arthur, Ont.
The Elms Hotel
457 Ladyard St.
Detroit - Mich. U.S.
26th Apr. 1927.

Sir,

I am visiting in Detroit & due to leave here for Canada within a week. I beg to offer myself for your consideration for the vacancy above advertised.

I have not a Canadian Cert., but I have been employed by the British Government as a Teacher in British Guiana, South America for over 30 years. My Certificate is from the B. Guiana Gov't & is Class I. I have taught there Elementary, Secondary High Schools & finally a Boys' College.

I have had experience also while here amongst the aboriginal Indians of the Colony & have always had a first-class record for results amongst all classes.
I resigned my appointment here less than a year ago mainly to get a change of climate. Since that time I have been on holiday in U.S.

I hold excellent references from the Commissioner of Education - Major Wm Gray & the Acting Gov. Lee - The Hon. T. Hampden - King both of Georgetown, Brit. Guiana.

These references of course take time if you think well to inquire, but meantime Mr. Wm L. Ryan, Farmers Bank Bldg., Pittsburgh, Pa.

a U.S. gentleman of high standing, who knows me well in B.C. will vouch for my credentials.

Any further inquiry I shall reply to immediately, but I should like to hear early as I have a post under consideration but prefer Indian work if I can get it.

Yours truly,

(Thos.) Louis Kennedy.

I forget -

I am R.C. Irish - age 40
The Elmo Hotel
457 Ledyard St.
Detroit, Mich., U.S.A.
27th April, 1927.

Sir,

I do not think I am persistent—or perhaps a nuisance. I do not mean to be so.

This morning I posted an application to you for the vacancy referred to in your ad.

I must confess that I did not greatly enter into the question of locality. I just concluded that as it was Indian it was in some remote spot. Since writing I located the spot from a map, and thought—struck me that if a man has previously held the post, you might consider it too lonely a spot for a woman.

If you give favorable consideration to
my application the question of loneliness be tried not trouble you. I am never lonely anywhere, though always alone. Also I have lived among the aboriginal Indians of British Guiana as well as the East Indians (from India) & taught them for years.

We found there also that women had far greater influence with the aborigines than men, with the exception perhaps of a P.C. priest. I am urging my application quite on my own because I have nobody else to urge it— at least, near enough to be of use.

I like Indians & would gladly be with them, though your Indians are a different type. Still, I know I would get on with them. Could you not give me a trial?

My Certificate is Class 5 from the Govt. of British Guiana, & I was trained as a Teacher in Dublin, Ireland before going to B. Guiana.

I had also in B. G. for four years the Training of Teachers for the work in
The Junior department of the Elementary School. I enclose for you a copy of the permit to give the heads of the B.C. Gov't Service as reference.

I have applied for another school, but if I could have the Indian School it appeals to me more than any other.

I mentioned that I am P.C. & have taught in P.C. schools always except when transferred to the College.

I have worked with Sisters in Convents often, & was educated by them.

I can say no more for myself. I must leave the result to you & God.

Sincerely yours,

(Tris) Lois Kennedy.

It is essential for me to get some employment at once, so if you consider the place let me know early.
Miss Lois Rosemary Kennedy while in the Service of the British Government in British Guiana as an Assistant Teacher at Queen's College for Boys also performed the duties set out in the schedule hereto, for the periods therein stated.

For information as to her character & qualifications she is permitted to invite reference to either of the undersigned.

W. Bain Gray, Major
Commissioner of Education

The Hon. T. Hampden King

Sir,

RE: Indian Day School, Pic Indian Reserve.

I wish to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 3rd inst., relative to the opening of an Indian Day School for the summer months on the Pic Reserve, and in reply I beg to advise I have communicated with the Reverend Joseph Couture, Nipigon, Ont., who is interested in the establishment of a school at this point, and the nomination of the services of a teacher, who would be suitable to carry on the work.

Referring to the latter paragraph of your letter I wish to advise I am leaving for Heron Bay this evening, and will make the necessary arrangements to have the old school building repaired, and will also arrange accommodation for the teacher.

With further reference to your letter of the 11th ultimo, your file number 9-7-1, relative to reopening the Indian Day School on the Pic Reserve, I beg to report I did not think it advisable to reopen the old school, as the roof was rather dilapidated, and, therefore, I made arrangements with the Reverend Brother Couture to rent the church for the schoolroom, and also the priest's quarters at the back of the church for the teacher's quarters.

As there is no road from the Pic Reserve to Heron Bay the furniture had to be taken down on a speeder from Heron Bay to the river, and from there I managed to have it transferred in a small gasoline boat.

The teacher is quite pleased with her surroundings and I am thoroughly convinced that the Indian parents will, no doubt, take advantage of the school and see that their children attend regularly. I presume the Department will erect a new school and teacher's residence this Fall on the Pic Reserve if the attendance is good during the summer months.

As the only mode of transportation from the Pic Reserve to Heron Bay—a distance of approximately seven miles—five miles by river and two miles by rail—is by river I would recommend purchasing a small, light rowboat for the teacher, as she is entirely isolated and has no means of getting off the Reserve.

An early reply will be appreciated.

Your obedient servant,

Indian Agent.

Sir:

I am enclosing herewith copy of a letter which I received from Miss L. Kennedy, who is teaching at the Pic Indian Day School, Heron Bay, Ont. As you will note all the school children have left with their parents to pick berries.

During the summer months the Indians on this Reserve and other Reserves in this Agency depend on the berry picking for their living. Consequently at this season of the year all Indians leave their Reserve and all go berry picking.

Miss Kennedy advised it would be useless to continue the school at this season of the year, and suggested that she close school, and proceed to Toronto where she would teach summer school for a few weeks. Consequently I advised her to close the school immediately, as I did not consider it advisable to keep the school open when all the children had left.

J. G. Burk, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Port Arthur, Ont.

Dear Sir:

Your telegram reached me today. I was pretty certain the Department intended no holidays this year, as the school was only opened temporarily during the summer months. I explained this to the Indians, but they are terribly thick-headed and could not see this.

They are glad to have the school and have kept the children steadily in attendance. The good lecture you gave them certainly had its effect, and as you can see by the report our attendance has been very good. The Indians are very pleased to see the children making good progress but argue that they have no hunting in the summer. Consequently they must take their children and go berry picking—where they average between $10.00 and $20.00 per day for each family—if the season is good and the berries are high.

For a time I thought it advisable to keep a sufficient number to keep open during August. In fact a fair number promised to stay, but their word is worth nothing. As soon as the berries began to ripen they went away, tent, baggage, and all, not even letting me know when they were going. I knew that since last week that the rest of the Indians were only waiting until the Bishop arrived—he was expect early this week. This morning a telegram came postponing the Bishop's visit to next year. Immediately all
the Indians left the Reserve for their berry picking grounds.

There are two or three very young children here. I could make a pretense of keeping the school open and draw my salary, but my conscience would not allow me to do this. Therefore, I thought it advisable to close school.

I could teach summer school in Toronto for a few weeks. Please advise me by wire if I have your permission to close school immediately.

I communicated with you before, and advised that the Indians would leave the Reserve during the berry season, but was advised by your stenographer that you had left for your Treaty Trip.

I have your wire and will close school tomorrow afternoon.

I am sure the Department will be very pleased when they realize that so many children are attending school, and you remarked during your last visit the children are making such good progress.

I wish to thank you very kindly for your trouble in hunting up the old baseball and basketball which you sent down. The children certainly enjoyed playing with them during their recess time.

Yours sincerely,

(Sgd) Miss L. Kennedy.

I feel it is really unnecessary for me to resign my position here unless you can arrange to pay me my grant for teaching each
of these subjects. My grant for Agriculture should be fifty dollars and also for Botanical science it is fifty. I am only getting $85 a month here, so unless I receive this $100 a year extra in grants, it is impossible to live here. It is lonely and very expensive. Dear Mr. Ferrier,

Some time ago, Mr. Burk spoke to me about Mrs. McDonnell, the teacher at Pic. It seems that this lady's husband is employed by one of the railway companies, and there has been considerable criticism of her holding a job as a teacher with so much distress prevalent.

At the time, I quite agreed with Mr. Burke, and told him that I was opposed, on general principles, to married women being employed in schools. But when I visited the Pic school, I came to the conclusion that, with the possible exception of Lake Helen, the best work of any school (day school, of course) in Mr. Burk's agency has been done at this very school.

Such a discovery naturally makes a difference, for, after all, the progress of the children is the main thing, and, to secure such progress, I should be inclined to overlook many things.

Mrs. McDonnell, however, is worrying about her position. I wish I knew whether you will be keeping her again next year. In discussing the matter the other day with Mr. Burk, I said that I would take the responsibility of recommending her retention, on the grounds of the work done, if the Department wished to keep her.

If she is to be retained, I think it would have a beneficial effect upon her work, if I could tell her that her being married will not be allowed to prejudicially affect her chances of reappointment.

With kindest regards,

Yours very sincerely,

W.J. Greening

Referring to the pulpwood project adjacent to the Pic Reserve at Heron Bay, Ont., I beg to report the Pic Reserve is comprised of two factions, namely Pic and Mobert Settlements, which is situated approximately 35 miles east of the Pic Reserve. The latter Settlement was established over 20 years ago by the Indians themselves, when the Hudson's Bay Company moved their Post from the mouth of the Pic River. The land at the Mobert Reserve was purchased by the Indians and is very poor sandy soil.

Before the hunting was exhausted the Mobert Indians were able to derive a very good living, but at the present time the hunting in this area is exhausted, and it is impossible for them to obtain work.

Over 90% of the families have moved back to the Pic Reserve, and are now engaged in cutting pulpwood. From information just received from the foreman, I have been told that the Pic group are doing exceptionally good work. The first week the Band only cut approximately $200.00, but the week ending August 28th, they cut $767.00 worth of wood, which is very encouraging.

There are two large companies operating on the Black River, which passes through the Pic Reserve. Both these companies are willing to co-operate with the Indians, and have assured me that they would give the Indians permanent work. At the present time I have secured a contract for the Band for 7000 cords. When this contract has been completed we will be able to secure a further contract.

At the present time the school teacher on the Mobert Reserve has been assisting with the organization of the pulpwood unit. I would strongly recommend that we make temporary arrangements to accommodate the children from the Mobert Reserve, who have moved to the Pic, and would suggest that Mrs. Reed, teacher of the Pic School, teach the girls in the forenoon and Mr. Douglas teach the boys in the afternoon. On the afternoons that Mrs. Reed is not teaching instructions will be given to certain Indians' homes on sewing, knitting, etc. The half days that Mr. Douglas does not teach will be spent organizing boys' classes, manual training, and also looking after camp supplies.

The two pulp companies expect to erect a hospital, and have agreed to get in touch with this office at some future date to discuss the possibility of erecting the hospital on the Reserve, and taking care of the Indians. This will eliminate a great deal of extra cost of Indians going from Reserves to hospitals, and will also save doctors' fees.

Referring to the school on the Mobert Reserve I would suggest that the school be taken down and rebuilt on the Pic Reserve. At the present time & I have not been able to secure cost prices, but a very reliable carpenter informed me the school could be cut into strips, 13 X 40, placed on flat cars, and removed to Heron Bay, and transferred there to the Reserve by our tractor.

A further report regarding the cost of removing the school will be sent at a later date. In the meantime I would be pleased if the Department would advise if the above mentioned plan will be approved.

Your obedient servant,

J. G. Burk,
Indian Agent.

Dear Mr. Burk,

I have just returned from summer study at the University of Toronto, and it is with regard to my future studies that I am writing this letter.

I am working towards my degree of Bachelor of Arts by correspondence study during the winter, and by attendance at the University during the summer. The winter study necessitates good mail facilities, for essays and exercises must be sent to the University at regular periods.
In my present position as teacher on the McIntyre Bay Reserve I am so far away from the railroad and from a post-office that it is quite impossible to send or receive mail regularly. This condition makes winter study very difficult. Two years ago I was taking a University course, but, after being able to carry on for two-thirds of the work, I was forced to discontinue because of the spring break-up. The resulting loss of time and money was rather discouraging; I had to take the same course again during the summer.

It would help me a great deal to be near the railroad, where mail is regular. I should like to continue teaching for the Department. Both these factors
prompt me to ask for an exchange to one of the Indian schools near the railroad, if such an exchange is possible. Dependable mail service would make it possible for me to keep on with my studies, and I must do.

I sincerely hope that you find it possible to secure the transfer; and I wish to express my appreciation now for any consideration you give to the matter.

Yours very truly,

Norman Van Hatten.

Dear Mr. Burk:

This letter tenders my resignation as teacher in the service of the Indian Department, and explains the reasons for such a step.

I have been employed in Indian Schools for three years. Those schools at which I worked were in the bush—so isolated that I was unable to do any extra-mural work at University. I was quite satisfied with such conditions, however, as I had the assurance of yourself and of the school Inspector that should an opening in a better location present itself, I should be given the opportunity to make an exchange. Such an opportunity soon occurred, but the preferable position was given to a new teacher imported from another District. I considered this an oversight, and remained with the Department. On returning from Summer School this year, I heard of a vacancy at the Heron Bay School. I applied to Ottawa for an exchange, but to my surprise, word came that the position had been filled by a teacher from the East. After a phone call to Mr. Phelan at Ottawa, I was assured that an exchange would be made, and that I would be teaching at the desired location on the Pic Reserve. I decided to accompany the new teacher to the McIntyre Bay Reserve and give him all possible assistance in getting settled. To this end I bought transportation to Orient Bay, and I met the train on which Mr. Murphy, the new teacher arrived. He refused, however, to accompany me to the McIntyre Bay Reserve, even though I repeated that word had come from the Department of the exchange.

In closing, I wish to express my sincere appreciation of the kind co-operation you have given me as a teacher in one of the Indian schools.

Yours very truly,

Sgd. Norman C. Van Hatten.
Ottawa,

Reverend Father Labelle has written us with reference to the under-mentioned schools:

(1) Moberg - He states that Miss Cox started teaching at this school but is being moved to Lake Helen because there was no wood for the kitchen stove. We have no communication from you regarding this matter and we cannot understand why she was transferred without the Department's approval. In addition, it is difficult to know why there was no wood. We have never refused any reasonable request from you for wood for any of the schools in your Agency but our file indicates that you have made no application this year for authority to purchase wood for any school in the Port Arthur Agency.

(2) Pic - We are advised that you were offered in August the names of six qualified teachers who were looking for schools. The Pic Indian Day School is situated at Heron Bay, Ontario, which is approximately 150 miles east of Port Arthur. The Ontario Paper Co., and Marathon Paper Company are operating within a short distance of our reservation, and have a townsite approximately 200 feet from the reservation. Miss Jeanne Lafrance,

Pic Indian Day School

Dear Miss Lafrance:

I have for answer your letter of December 12 with a request for information concerning the Pic and Seine River Indian Day Schools.

The Pic School is situated at Heron Bay, Ontario, approximately 150 miles east of Port Arthur, Ontario. The Ontario Paper Company and the Marathon Paper Company are operating within a short distance of the reservation, and have a town site now only two hundred feet from the reservation.

One of our former teachers, Mr. J. Douglas, is teaching at the town site and will, I am certain, be able to give you a great deal of helpful advice in your work.

The building is a combination school and teacher's residence. It is furnished and our Department supplies the fuel. We do not supply blankets or linen. There are some twenty children in attendance.

The unfortunate thing with regard to this school is that we have already offered it tentatively to another teacher. The Seine River School is in a rather isolated locality, and I am writing to Mr. Indian Superintendent Lockhart for information.

Sincerely yours,

Bernard F. Neary,
Superintendent of Education.

A teacher on an Indian Reserve finds teaching only one portion of his many visits, duties. Dear Sir,

Yesterday evening the Chief was at the Station when I got here Thursday, but he said I had better wait until next day and he would have school scrubbed and some cuts so he came back on Friday evening for me. He appears to be a kind man.

I find Mr. Donnelly as you said they have very few tools in fact very little & more than the school room! There is a whole slate and not a slate pencil.
Listening on the
porch outside of the door
quite nervous when I think
of it. There was a padlock on the out-
side but it was a broken one and
on the inside I have to keep a stick
of wood to keep it shut.
On Saturday it was dreadfully cold
the snow and wind was coming in
my neck up stairs.
Commenced school today Monday
there was 21 scholars, 12 girls & 9 boys
all very nice children.
The people tell me their will be quite
a number more in June.
I had quite a time to keep the
trees employed without slate
oil. The black board needs
coat of black paint there
chalk will hardly make
brown on it.
I do not see how the teacher managed
as there is neither a pail for the child
nor to carry water for a drink, nor
a broom to sweep the school floor.

I should like Mr. Donalds if you
could send down

24 slates and a box of slate pencils
& simple arithmetic
6 first readers
6 second readers
35 alphabet lesson cards
ink, pens and chalk
also lesson 3, 4, and 6 lesson cards
I should very much to have one
geography. I you would kindly
send along with

Ottawa
About $2.50 drawing brick from C.P.R. station in winter time by a sleigh road to school 5 miles $2.50 in the summer time this sleigh road is impassable would then cost about $5.00 as it has to be taken along C.P.R. track one mile to the river, then down 100 feet bank, then down the river 5 miles, then from river to school house about 200 feet or so, the freight on brick from here to Heron Bay Station is $3.2 cents per 100 lbs. 32 pounds to a brick (or about) coming $10.50 Mason work about 2 days at $2.50 = $5.00 as there is no mason nearer than Schreiber $2.50 each day = $5.00 making an approximate cost of $32.50 No Indians on the reserve can build a chimney and there is not a chimney in any house on the Pie Reserve that I am aware of, I may mention that the teachers residence and the school house at the Pays Plat Reserve have no chimneys and would cost about $15.00 each as they would be shorter and easier of access with the brick etc and the mason nearer, there has never been a house burned on this reserve and nor a chimney on it— one house burned on the Pie Reserve in twenty years.

Memorandum—fpr Secretary.

The school building on the Pic Reserve is a very inferior one, and it is thought to be certainly preferable to erect another building, rather than repair this old, dilapidated log structure. It is thought wise to do this at once.

Provision must be made in the Supplementary Estimates for next year, as the Pic Band has no funds which could assist in the erection. Probably $600.00 would be required to erect a sufficiently commodious building. In default of this being done, it is absolutely necessary to repair the old building. If $200.00 were spent upon it next spring it might serve for 2 or 3 years longer. This amount would also have to be provided in the Supplementary Estimates. Mr. Hodder and I left the Reserve with the understanding that the chiefs and the school teacher should make a thorough examination of the building and estimate the requirements for proper repair.

They do not seem to have done as they promised they would, but from what I saw I should judge that $200.00 would cover the necessary repairs.

Ottawa, 27th August, 1904.

Memorandum:

When at Pic River recently I visited the School, which, however, was not in session at the time. I found the building to be in a very bad condition of repair and altogether in my opinion unfit for use. The floors are rotten and the foundation has so given way that the whole building has sunk so that the door at the entrance cannot be closed. The building is also very damp and in every respect in an unsanitary condition.

I inclose a letter handed me by the Chief relating to this matter. Chief Desmoulin informed me that if a grant were given towards putting up a new school building the Indians would be willing to assist in its erection.

The Indians also state that the present Teacher, Moses Madwayosh, is unfit to hold the position owing to old age and infirmity; Madwayosh is about 76 years of age and the Indians informed me that he has no control whatever over the children. They stated also that Madwayosh speaks altogether in Indian to the children and that they have not, therefore, an opportunity to learn English, which they consider one of the most important objects desired in sending children to the School.

The Priest, to whom I spoke regarding this matter, said that, while Madwayosh is not as competent as he would desire, the difficulty in the way of dispensing with his services is that he has no one in view whom he could recommend to succeed him.

Assistant Secretary.
Department of Indian Affairs.

Mr. Euclid Bonin, who signs himself as Acting Indian Agent, calls attention to the need for a new school building on the Pie reserve, and states that the Rev. Ottawa, February 31, 1906.

Sir,

The attention of the Department has been called to the urgent need for a new school-house on the Pic reserve, the present building being very old and totally unfit for school purposes.

The Department has had an offer from the Rev. Father Dugas to dispose of the church there for about the sum of $300 but before considering the matter would like to have a report from you as to the value of the building, whether it can be made suitable for school purposes and, if so, at what cost. Regarding the school situation in this Agency I beg to submit the following report:

We now have three day schools situated at the following Reserves: Port William, Lake Helen, and Sand Point. The Sand Point school and also the one situated on the Pic Reserve were opened temporarily this year as summer schools to ascertain if the parents would send their children to school regularly.

The school opened on the Pic Reserve was conducted in the Roman Catholic Church. The old school house, a log structure, is in a very dilapidated condition and if repaired would only be fit for a storehouse. The teacher, Miss Kennedy, reported a good attendance and carried on successfully considering most adverse circumstances. The Indians on this Reserve complained about the school being held in the church—this adding to the difficulties of the teacher.

The Reserve is situated in a most isolated spot 7 miles from Heron Bay on the Canadian Pacific Railway. The only mode of transportation in the summer is by water and a walk of 2½ miles from the C.P.R. Bridge to Heron Bay. Consequently it will be impossible to retain the services of a qualified teacher until a permanent school and residence has been built at this point.

The majority of the Indians have built permanent homes at the Pic Reserve and do not take their families to their trapping grounds as in the past. They are most anxious to have a permanent school. Several families are camping at White River and Port Coldwell in order to take advantage of school facilities at these points.

I feel that a school and residence is urgently needed on this Reserve, and would recommend the construction of same next spring.

At the Sand Point Reserve two old log buildings were purchased this summer to conduct a temporary school. The buildings are still answering the purpose of a temporary school and residence, but are not suitable for permanent buildings. Mr. F. H. Paget, Chief Accountant, of our Department, inspected these two buildings last summer and could vouch for their inadequacy as permanent school buildings. On my last visit to this Reserve the majority of the
To The Secretary,

Indians had left for their trapping grounds leaving their wives and children on the Reserve to take advantage of the school.

As this school has proved to be a success I would recommend the construction of a new school and residence next spring on the Sand Point Reserve.

At Gull Bay Reserve there are between 30 and 35 children of school age. The parents of these children have built permanent homes and are most anxious to have school facilities for their children on this Reserve. The old school at Gull Bay has not been opened for a number of years.

During the last three years on every visit to Gull Bay this matter has been brought to my attention, and I have taken no action owing to the fact that I have housed and educated the children in the St. Joseph's Boarding School. I find here, as on all other Reserves in this Agency, a strong desire on the part of the parents to have their children with them, as well as a growing prejudice against Boarding Schools. I have done all in my power to encourage the parents to send their children to the Boarding School but with little success.

As there are so many children on the Gull Bay Reserve receiving no education I would also recommend the erection of a new school and residence at this point.

The Indians on the above mentioned Reserves are gradually taking up farming and have built permanent homes. The Indian Day Schools not only educate the children but the whole family in modern way of living and in sanitary habits. I would recommend that provision be made in the estimates for the erection of schools and teachers' residences at Pic, Sand Point, and Gull Bay Reserves.

The approximate cost of these buildings would be $20,000.00

Your obedient servant,

J. G. Burk,

Memorandum:

Honourable Charles Stewart,

Last year, the Department re-opened the Pie Indian Day School, near Heron Bay, in the Fort William Agency. As an interim arrangement, class was held in the church and temporary living quarters were secured for the teacher. The activity was so successful, that I placed in the Main Estimates an item of $5,000 to provide for a combined classroom and teacher's residence.

In view of the situation of this reserve, it is considered advisable to have the building programme undertaken by day labour - the materials to be purchased by Mr. Agent Burk, of Fort Arthur. He can engage a competent foreman-carpenter, who would be responsible for the work, which, in the main, would be performed by Indian and other local labour.

A plan was forwarded to Mr. Burk and he has estimated the cost at approximately $4,700. Department officers are satisfied that the proposal is a good one but are convinced that the cost will require all of the appropriation for the purpose.

I am now requesting your authority for this expenditure. A considerable saving will be effected if the materials can be freighted from the railroad to the reserve while the snow is on the ground.

Duncan C. Scott

Sir:

I beg to report I just received a communication from Miss Kathleen O'Hara, teacher of the Pic Indian Day School, requesting me to communicate with the Department regarding the advisability of ordering food supplies for the children's noon day lunch, and also a hot meal before the children leave the school in the afternoon.

The weather has been frightfully cold this winter. This combined with extremely poor rapping 95% of the children are undernourished. Under the existing circumstances I would suggest that provisions be ordered for the children's noon day lunch and a hot bowl of porridge before they leave for their homes in the afternoon.

For Cooking Classes & Noonday Meal.
20 lbs. Sugar,
50 lbs. Flour,
10 lbs. Klim,
2 doz. Eggs,
5 tins cocoa,
2 lbs. Butter,
1 lb. Baking Powder,
2 lbs. Raisins.

For Sewing Classes.
3 Packets Needles,
15 yds. Flannelette,
3 yds. White Yarn,
5 Spools Thread,
15 yds. Cheesecloth.

An early reply regarding the above will be appreciated.

Your obedient servant,

J. C. Bury,
Indian Agent.

Replying to your letter of the 6th instant, I have to say that you may arrange for the purchase and delivery of the following supplies for the use of the Pic Indian Day School: 2 inexpensive door mats, 24 tin bowls, 24 spoons, 3 inexpensive roller towels and 1 wash basin.

Sir:

I beg to report I have just received a communication from Mr. Downey, teacher of the Pic Indian Day School, reporting that the condition of the Indians on the Pic Reserve is becoming very serious, as the Indians have not been able to derive a living by hunting, and he pointed out the children are undernourished, and recommended a noon-day lunch, as some of the children live considerable distance from the school.

Dear Mr. Burk;—

I have yours of the 8th in regards to Coal Oil supplied the Pic River Indian School.

May say for your information that most of this difference in price is accounted for in the freight charges from Fort William and Port Arthur to Heron Bay, a distance of approximately one hundred and ninety miles.

A drum or barrel containing 45 gallons of Coal Oil weighs about from 450 to 460 lbs, and is shipped as 3rd class matter at a rate of .77 1/2 cents per hundred pounds making a cost of about $3.50. Freight charges for the #3 45 gallons, then there is a charge of $1.15, for returning the empty container, if the empty container is not returned there is a further charge of $8.00 for each container retained, you will notice that the freight charges on the barrel of oil and the charges on returning the empty is about $4.65, just about 10 cents per gallon on the oil above what your city dealers have to pay, then I understand the oil company in cities deliver the oil to the retailers in their oil trucks at no extra cost to the retailers while we in the small country places have to accept delivery of the oil at the Railway station and take it to our place of business empty same into our tanks and return the empty to the railway station to be returned to the oil company, of course this expense expense is not very great but it all adds to the cost of the oil.

I think if you will ask your local freight Agent you will find that my figures in regards to freight charges are approximately correct.

Trusting this will explain the difference in charges.

Yours Truly,

Dear Mr. Burk, I wish to draw to your attention and also the Department the state of the water supply for the school.

The Pic River is very muddy and dirty and unfit for use. Only at certain seasons of low water is it clear. The river is at least two hundred yards from the school and all water used must be carried in pails. Some days ten to fifteen pails are needed.

There is neither sink nor pump here. A cheap pump would save carrying from the river, particularly in winter, and would be a help in case of fire for which there is no protection at present.

I think it very essential to have a pump house on a Reserve; the teacher suffers many inconveniences which cannot be remedied.

Yours truly,

Sir:

I beg to enclose herewith letter which is self-explanatory, received from Mr. Downey, teacher of the Pic Indian Day School. I would suggest that a pump be purchased for the Pic School.

I may say the water supply on the Pic Reserve is very poor, as the Pic River has a clay bottom, and the water is muddy at all times. The spring in the wintertime on the Reserve freezes, and the Indians and teacher are obliged to obtain the water from the River. I may say that the water cannot be used until it has settled as there is a great deal of sediment in the water.

Sir:

I beg to report I have just received a communication from Mr. C. S. Downey, teacher of the Pic Indian Day School, advising that the coal oil stove is beyond repair.

I may say this stove has given a great deal of trouble in the last year, and the teacher recommends the purchase of an inexpensive cook stove. He states they use approximately 5 gallons of oil a month, which costs $2.00. During the year the cost of coal oil would amount to approximately $20.00 to $25.00. A good cook stove could be purchased for $35.00. Under the circumstances I would suggest that a wood stove be purchased for this school.

The teacher has borrowed a tin stove from one of the Indians, which could be used for a temporary cook stove until authorization has been received regarding the above.

Sir:

I regret I overlooked reporting on my recent visit to the Pic Indian Day School, the teacher asked if it would be possible to purchase paint and kalsomine to redecorate the residence of the Pic School. I may say that the residence has not been decorated for some years. The teacher advised that if the material was purchased they would gladly do the painting and kalsomining. The total cost, including brushes, would not exceed $29.05.

As this is one of the isolated schools where the teacher does not come in contact with any white people I would strongly recommend the above request.

Your obedient servant,

Sir: Pic I. D. School

Referring to your letter of the 20th ultimo, file 1941E-Ont. regarding school repairs, I beg to enclose herewith requisition covering the material required, for the above school.

Labor to paint and make repairs should not exceed an amount of $100.00 and I would be pleased if the Department would forward an advance cheque for this amount, as soon as the material is purchased or authorized for purchase through this office.

Your obedient servant,

J. G. Burk, Indian Agent.

The Secretary,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Dept. of Mines & Resources,
Ottawa, Ont.

Encl.
Ottawa,
June 27, 1941.

Dear Sir:

I am in receipt of your letter of the 24th instant regarding the repairs and painting required at the Pic School. Purchase of the articles shown on the attached requisition may be made from a firm on the approved list. Arrangements will be made to forward to you the amount required for labour.

Yours truly,

R.A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

Mr. J.G. Burk,
Indian Agent,
Port Arthur, Ont.
Port Arthur, Ont.,
October 7, 1941.

Attention-Supt. of Welfare & Training

Sir:

I beg to refer you to my letter of October 6th, with regard to flood water in the Gull Bay school, and have to advise that the basement of the Pic School is in a similar condition.

It will be necessary to put men to work immediately and I have estimated the cost very roughly at $40.00. Would you kindly authorize this work as soon as possible and forward a cheque for this amount to cover labour.

It is presumed that should any saving be made on the cost of this work, at either the Gull Bay, Mobert or Pic school, same may be applied on any one of the three schools and every effort will be made to keep the cost as low as possible.

Your obedient servant,

J. G. Burk, Indian Agent.

The Secretary,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Dept. of Mines & Resources,
Ottawa, Ont.
Ottawa, October 10, 1941.

Dear Sir:

I desire to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 6th instant, with regard to the Gull Bay School, and also your letter of the 7th instant, in respect to the Pic School.

You may make arrangements to have the basements at both these schools drained. It is our hope that Indian labour will be available for this work.

An accountable cheque for $30.00 is being sent forward to you to cover the cost of labour. It is scarcely necessary to add that this work should be undertaken and completed at the earliest possible date.

Yours truly,

R. A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare and Training.

Mr. J. O. Burk,
Indian Agent,
Port Arthur, Ont.
Ottawa,
October 14, 1941.

Wood shed. 10 x 12.

Well - in the wrong place.

In the slope toward the river, drains the whole school ground.

No water in winter in the well.

Eight feet of snow on top of it.

In summer, four inches of hard water.

Hope the Agent Burt will have time to discuss. His matter when he comes.

J. Alls.

Indian Affairs Br., Dep't of Mines & Resources, Ottawa, Ontario.

Repairs - Pic Indian Day School.

Your above letter requests more details of the work to be done at the Pic School.

The outside walls of this school have now all been covered with insul brick siding which should make the building easier to heat this coming winter. The window sashes and ledges were pretty rotten and now have been all replaced. The porches were sagging and the flooring (or the porches) rotten in some places and a start has been made to remedy this, but as our current advance for repairs is now all expended it has not been possible to complete this job.

Insulation of the school building is also a necessity, for this school is in the cold White River area. It is desired to have a new shingle job done over the entire roof, as the present cedar shingles are soft and rotten; for this job, I would recommend fire-proof asphalt shingles. Further, the window panes need re-puttying, as the present putty has become bone-dry and is loosening from the panes. Both the class-room and living quarters are in need of kalsomining, and a small amount of interior painting is required.

This school had been closed for two years prior to reopening in January. There has been little maintenance to the building for three or four years and I recommend having this building put in first-class shape, such as is the school at Mobert.

To complete repairs, etc., the sum of $400.00 is required for materials and freight and I estimate that $175.00 is required for wages. This is more than was provided for in the 1947/48 estimates, but it was not realized that repairs to such an extent would be required and also that the rise in building material prices was greater than anticipated.

The materials required can be obtained locally from the Milton-François Lumber Co., who have supplied us with most of our building materials in the past. This company have been supplied with a copy of our standard day-school plans. Your authority for local purchase of materials to an amount not exceeding $400.00, and for an advance of $175. for wages is requested, please.

J.G. Burk, Indian Agent.

P.S. The $400. for materials includes freight from Port Arthur to Baron Bay and haulage to the reserve, which will run around $75. We have an Indian who is a qualified carpenter available to do the work.

Indian Affairs Branch
Department of Mines & Resources, Ottawa, Ont.

Attention: EDUCATIONAL DIVISION

Re: Pic Indian Day School
Heron Bay, Ontario

This Agency is in receipt of a letter from Miss G. Creese, teacher at the above school, in which she has drawn our attention to the need of two ladders on either side of the roof incline at the school. During a recent gale, an Indian on the reserve inspected the chimney of the School, and had considerable difficulty in doing so. He noted that several bricks on the chimney were loose. As a safeguard against fire hazard, your authority to have these two ladders put on the roof and also the rebricking of loose bricks in the chimney is requested. We might add here that the chimney walls and stove pipes were immediately given a very thorough cleansing following this episode.

Permission is also requested to engage a man to clean out a well from which the school obtains its water supply. Miss Creese has remarked that this job is a necessity for their now is no snow, and she has to draw her water from a creek a quarter mile distant. If the well were cleaned out, it would avoid this long trip. I will advise Miss Creese that when the well is cleaned out, to send water samples down here for our transmission to the provincial laboratories for testing purposes. It is considered advisable to do this before the water is used to avoid any danger of contamination.

NVP/lmp (for) J. G. Burk, Superintendent.

DATE 19th May, 1948, Fort Arthur, Ont.
Indian Affairs Branch, Dept. of Mines & Resources, Ottawa, Ont.

School Repairs, Pic Indian Day School.

A recent survey of the above school has shown the need of carrying out certain repairs, to prevent deterioration of the structure.

Two of the verandahs require replacement of flooring, as well as renewal of the pilings. The basement wall on the outside has developed several expanding cracks which should be recemented. The flooring in the cloakroom has heaved about three inches, indicated a dislocation underneath which condition should be investigated and remedied. The school interior had a first-class decorating job last year, but the exterior trim needs re-doing. If funds are short, the exterior painting could be shelved until next season, but we feel that the fore-mentioned repairs should be given consideration.

We have on hand about $75. on building materials from a previously uncompleted job at this school, which has been kept in safe and dry storage in the school. We estimate a further $75. in building materials would be required, with major carpentering work being a necessity and undoubtedly would run around $150.00.

It appears altogether likely that we shall secure the services of a teacher this September and we would like to have the building in good condition. Regardless of whether we do have the school operating, it would be a sound policy to carry out these repairs so that the building's condition will not suffer through lack of attention.

J.G. Burk, Indian Sup't.

Memorandum:

DEPUTY MINISTER,

Pic Indian Day School

As part of the Welfare program instituted on the various reserves across Canada, we are digging wells on the Pic Reserve near Heron Bay. This work is being done by the Hasquoil's Bros., 228 W. Gore Street, Fort William, Ontario.

While this company has its well-digging crew on the reserve, we would like to have a well dug also at the school.

For many years we have been unable to hold a teacher at this school for any length of time due to the lack of water. At the present time the teacher has to pack water in buckets from the Pic river which runs some sixty-five feet below the level of the school building. In the winter when the path is icy, it is almost impossible for a woman teacher to pack water up this path. I attach two photographs taken recently on this reserve when the Superintendent of Education inspected the school. One picture is taken part way up the slope from the river and indicates the steepness of the incline.

I would, therefore, recommend for your approval the hiring of the Hasquoil's Bros. to dig a well on this reserve at a cost of $5.50 a foot at a depth not to exceed two hundred feet. The welldiggers estimate that this is the outside depth of the well as they will have to go a considerable depth beyond the river bed.

Director.

PIC INDIAN DAY SCHOOL INSPECTION REPORT

Date of Inspection - September 27, 1949.

Location of School
This school is located about three miles from the C.P.R. railway station at Heron Bay, Ontario. There are really three settlements at Heron Bay namely:
(a) The stores and hotel at the railway station.
(b) The Indian village.
(c) The town site of the Ontario Pulp and Paper Company.

This company owns logs in the Heron Bay district and they are shipped by a long flume to nearby bays where they are shipped to the United States, (for the Chicago Tribune).

This also is a good spot for a married couple. The town site is but ten minutes walk from the Indian school and the railway station is about twenty-five or thirty minutes walk. The roads are quite good and taxi service is available. In fact, groceries are delivered from the store at the station to the school. The building is in good condition and is similar to the one at Mobert. It has a well lighted classroom and the attached teachers' quarters have recently been painted. There are two rooms upstairs and linoleum rugs are required and have recently been ordered.

Teacher and classroom activities.
The teacher, Miss E. Lingley is 39 years of age and has a first class Nova Scotia certificate with eleven years of teaching experience. She seems to be a capable teacher and is bright and intelligent. She was formerly employed as clerk, Grade 3 at His Majesty's dockyards in Halifax. She naturally needs a little practice but with experience should develop into a really efficient teacher. Both Mr.
Greening and I were pleased with her work in the classroom.

The pupils are bright but show evidence of poor teaching in the past.

As a result I spent a great deal of time with this teacher explaining to her our system of reports, requisitions, etc.

Recommendations:

1. There is a part basement to this school. We should consider the installation of a furnace at a later date.

2. A well should be dug to provide an adequate supply of water.

3. The attendance at this school should be watched as it may eventually require two teachers.

Bernard F. Neary,
Supt. of Indian Education.

Dear Col:

I just received a very snappy letter from Miss Lingley, our teacher at Heron Bay, complaining that very little cooperation has been received regarding the purchase of equipment, etc. for her school at Heron Bay.

It was my understanding at the time of your visit, that you were making a list of all her requirements and would order direct from Ottawa.

I quite understand that teachers who are in isolated spots should have 100% cooperation, and I certainly regret that this friction has developed. I am therefore making a trip to Heron Bay almost immediately and will see what I can do to make her happy.

The requisition for Queen heaters was delayed somewhat as Fairbanks-Morse advised there was a shipment of space heaters expected by boat almost daily and they would let me know as soon as possible regarding the price and shipping date. At the present time they have not arrived but are expected almost any day.

I was very highly criticized by Mrs. Burk for not asking how the papoose situation is. Very kind regards.

Yours sincerely,

J.G. Burk,
Indian Superintendent.

Dear Col. Neary:

I was sorry it was necessary to phone you yesterday, but the man in charge of the drilling on the Pic Reserve continued drilling past the 95 ft. mark. Apparently they drilled 162 ft. Mr. Hacquoil was notified the day before yesterday, and got in touch with me when I returned to the office yesterday afternoon.

We were all very much surprised when they did not hit water at 30 or 40 ft. Even the manager of the Ontario Pulp and Paper Company thought we would hit water at 35 ft. However, we will only drill to 200 ft. and will wire you regarding the results, that is, of course, if we do not hit water.

Apparently one of your films must have been mixed up with mine, and consequently I am enclosing the negatives and snaps.

We are now having wonderful weather at the Head of the Lakes, and I hope it will continue for another few weeks.

With very kind regards,

Yours sincerely,

J. G. Burk,
Indian Superintendent.

Dear Mr. Burk:

There was no delay at all in ordering the supplies for Miss Lingley. By now you will have received Purchase Order 49053 covering her various requirements in the way of furniture.

In our letter of September 30 we authorized the purchase of the janitor's supplies needed.

Recently we have also ordered a book-case, two pieces of blackboard and seventeen gallons of paint for the school.

We have also sent over a requisition for the space heater, the range oil burner and the camp heater required at this school. By now some of these supplies will have arrived for Miss Lingley and she will appreciate the fact that we are not forgetting her in any way whatsoever. With regard to the question in the last paragraph of your letter, you may advise Mrs. Burk that we have just had twins; one a boy and one a girl. In fact my wife has asked me to inquire of you as to whether you can get a papoose basket for her. If it is at all possible I would like very much to have one for her and will gladly pay for it.

With regard to the pictures I can understand how our films got mixed up but you did not enclose the negatives and snaps. I presume that I will be receiving them soon. In conclusion may I again thank you and Mrs. Burk for the hospitality shown me during my trip to the Head of the Lakes.

I am enclosing you a copy of the Indian Day School Regulations, which will show the number of days the school should be open each year, the holidays and the methods of computing the salaries of teachers.

The caretaker is expected to sweep the school-room daily and scrub it at frequent intervals and also to light the fire and have the school-room warm when the children arrive in the morning. Dear Sir,

During the past quarter at Port Elgin I have had an opportunity of estimating the cost of living. Supplies are brought to us by mail carrier four miles to nearest store and fourteen to Wiarton. In reply to your favor of November 29, 1921 regarding the establishing of a Community Centre at above named school I beg to inform you that our resident Methodist Minister and I have carried on the work successfully until the present date, beginning in November 29/21.

Do you consider it just to judge?

I have spent four years in high school learning "what" to teach and one year in teachers' training school learning "how."
to teach and after having successful experience in white schools, I feel that I can handle the work in an Indian school of this size. My former inspectors, Mr. R. Leslie of Peterborough or Mr. Mr. Dougall, M.A. of Petrolia would give my records in their schools if applied to. Also Mr. Mr. Cook's report may be referred to.

J.R.C. stated that pupils did not know alphabet. For many years the A-B-C system has run out of date in connection with teaching Primary Reading; proof of which may be found page 4 of East Reading Manual authorized by Ministry of Education. The Phonetic or Sound Method in conjunction with other new methods are the authorized plans of teaching now. I teach by the instruction laid down.
This Teachers' Manual, used in the Normal and Model Schools of Ontario. The pupils learn the alphabet names in order and their recognition incidentally. The sound or Phonie system is the outstanding one. In teaching words which do not easily analyze into sounds we use the Look and Say method to assist.

For two years now Solomon has been at various times manufacturing ammunition by which he hopes to have his removal from this school. Elliott is more too bright and much of the time had been a "Swamp" Distiller. The last few months he has been neglecting his official calls, having made his since June. He comes in about between 10 AM and 10.30 and does some bent work being practiced for 15 or 20 minutes after the children have finished Reading, Literature, Phonics and Spelling. He makes a case out of that and tries to impress the people Council Day that pupils learn nothing.
However Wednesday following Council he came to me to say he intended to take back the false words he had placed before the people and would do so by interviewing the Chief Agent and Secretary. If he does so I shall make no charge against his neglect of duty if he will begin anew and keep silence down.

I am to go after everyone holding positions on the reserve. When I first came here he was after Rev. Hilditch because he was making him keep his place. Mr. H. Would not stand for stealing from Collective Plate. He elected himself Choir leader after Mr. Johnston's death, making an attempt to discharge the organist whom he did not like. Because Rev. C. I do not like to trouble Mr. Morse as he has enough of that to deal with now; although he knows this.

My piano being used in the school seems to annoy one or two women. They want me to teach them to be piano players in a few weeks. Several wanted me to give piano lessons but they have a competent teacher here and anyway I have not time for it.

When I train the children for concert work I find that takes all my time outside of study hours.

Mr. Dr. Cool thought at his last visit that the children were progressing splendidly. They are becoming quite conversant with English, both written and in conversation. Supplying Miss Moffatt Entrance Material for years. Those children are exceptionally clever. They stay at school whereas at Pt. L. Sir:

I beg to report an epidemic of chicken pox at Port Elgin School on this reserve and that I have given orders to close this School for ten days at least.

On Friday Dec 5th, I received a letter from the teachers of the School that there were only six children at School and that the rest were sick at home with a skin disease, which was thought to be smallpox and I at once called a doctor from Wiarton to examine some of the children and he pronounced it a type of chicken pox and as it was making good progress and spreading rapidly, advised the closing of the School and I at once gave orders to that effect.

If a marked improvement is shown that it has been checked and is not spreading and does not turn into something worse, I shall hope to open the School in ten days or two weeks.

you did not arrive but later went there alone and afterwards said that you did not see anything to complain of. Sir:-

I beg to make the following report regarding conditions at present existing, at No 3, Fort Elgin School, on this Reserve.

Complaints have been received at this office, also been brought to the monthly Council meeting, that the teacher of the Fort Elgin School, Mrs Bell, has been far too strict with the pupils. I have twice visited this school recently, to investigate the matter, and to thoroughly talk the matter over with Mrs Bell. I beg to enclose a letter from Mr Snider, solicitor, of Wiarton, to whom, it was declared that Mrs Bell struck one of the children. Mrs Bell utterly denied this charge to me, and personally, I have always found her fair to the pupils. Gregor Keenig, at present, refuses to allow his children to return to school- as he is demanding an investigation.

Regarding the charge of the children not being allowed in the school before 9 a.m., I believe this to be correct. At recess time, I consider the teacher is doing the right thing when she makes them go out, as this is necessary for fresh air and exercise. During my last visit to the school, I made it a point to be there at the noon hour, and the children were all in, eating their lunch.

If it is possible for the Department to have this matter officially investigated, I consider it would be advisable, and at the same time, another matter could be dealt with, namely, that of the estate of the late Henry Jennsten, his heirs being anxious for a settlement.

Enclosure.

Secretary,

Dept. of Ind. Affs.

With Cheque

Sir,

I have to acknowledge the receipt of your letter undated enclosing the December quarter return of the Port Elgin Day School, as well as an order from Mr. Jones to make his quarterly cheque payable to you.

In reply I beg to say that a cheque for $100.00, being the amount of the quarterly salary due, made payable to you is enclosed herewith. Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean
