Ottawa, August 13th, 1928.

Sir:

Replying to your letter of the 7th instant, enclosing the applications which you received for the position as teacher of the Port Elgin Indian Day School, and also with reference to the application of Mrs. Sarah Bell, I have to confirm the following telegram to you of the 11th instant:

"Appoint Mrs. Sarah Bell as teacher Port Elgin School."

The Department has noted the qualifications of Mrs. Bell, as well as the recommendation of yourself and the Public School Inspector, and is, therefore, pleased to approve of Mrs. Bell's appointment. The salary allowed her will be at the rate of $90 per month for the ten teaching months in the year.

Mrs. Bell should arrange to begin duties on September 4th, next, the date on which the schools reopen after the present summer holidays. You should notify her of her appointment and inform the Department definitely as to whether she accepts the position or not and will begin duties on the date mentioned. We hope that Mrs. Bell will meet with every success in her work at this school.

If at any time Mrs. Bell proposes to have her husband live on the reserve, you should correspond with the Department in the matter.

The other applications which you forwarded are returned herewith. Mrs. Tupper's application is being held as I am offering her another position.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Acting Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

A. D. Moore, Esq.,
Indian Agent,

Ottawa, July 8, 1944.

Memorandum:

REPRESENTATIVE OF THE TREASURY

Re: Port Elgin Indian Day School, No. 420.

Please note that Miss Gladys R. Parke has resigned, effective July 1, 1944, and no further payment of salary should be made to her.

For Deputy Minister.
Ottawa,
September 12, 1944.

Memorandum:

REPRESENTATIVE OF THE TREASURY

Re: Port Elgin Indian Day School
No. 420

In my memorandum of July 8, 1944, I advised you that Miss Gladys R. Parke had resigned as teacher of the above-mentioned school. To succeed her the Department has appointed Miss Gwendolyn M. Ward at a salary of $90 a teaching month, plus bonus, effective September 1, 1944. I enclose copy of letter of appointment and the other forms will be forwarded to you when received.

for Deputy Minister.
Ottawa, April 15, 1946.

Memorandum:

REPRESENTATIVE OF THE TREASURY.

Re: Port Elgin Indian Day School, No. 420,

In my memorandum of March 20, 1946, I advised you that the teacher Miss G. Ward would give up duties at this school on April 15, 1946.

To succeed her, we have appointed Mrs. Vera Lavallee at a salary of $100.00 a teaching month. Her appointment is effective from May 1, 1946, and she should be paid for the months of May and June, but no further payment should be made to her unless we specifically request such action.

Mrs. Lavallee is an Indian and a member of the Cape Croker Band and, consequently, is not liable for income tax.

I enclose copy of letter of appointment and other documents will be sent to you when received.

For Deputy Minister.

Knei.
Ottawa, March 20, 1946.

Memorandum:

REPRESENTATIVE OF THE TREASURY

Re: Port Elgin Indian Day School,
No. 420.

Please note that the Department has received and accepted the resignation of the teacher, Miss G. Ward, effective April 18, 1946, and no further payment or salary should be made to her after that date.

For Deputy Minister.
Ottawa, 18 October 1946.

Memorandum:

REPRESENTATIVE OF THE TREASURY

Re: Port Elgin Indian Day School No. 420

In memorandum of April 15, 1946, you were advised of the appointment of Mrs. Vera Lavallee. We have just been advised that she resumed duties on Sept. 1, 1946 and consequently she should be paid salary from that date at the rate of $125.00 a teaching month.

Mrs. Lavallee is an Indian and a member of the Cape Croker Band and consequently is not liable for income tax.

Ottawa, May 16, 1914.

His Royal Highness

The Governor General in Council,

The undersigned has the honour to report that it being necessary to erect a new school house on the Cape Croker reserve in the province of Ontario, tenders were called for the construction of the building, receivable up to noon of the 4th instant.

Only one tender was received, being that of Messrs. Gilpin Bros., of Wainton, for $5,700.00, who furnished the required security deposit equal to 10% of the contract price.

The undersigned would recommend, pursuant to the requirements of sub-section 2 of section 36 of the Public Works Act, that the contract be awarded to Messrs. Gilpin Bros., for the amount of their tender, $5,700.00, the Architect of the Department having reported that this tender is fair and reasonable, his estimate for the construction of the building being $5,800.00.

The undersigned would also recommend that authority be granted under the provisions of section 90 of the Indian Act, for the expenditure of the above sum being charged to the capital of the Cape Croker band, which amounts to
$356,332.46, the necessary resolution of the Council of the band having been received by the Department of Indian Affairs that the expenditure for the construction of this school be taken from their funds.

Superintendent General of Indian Affairs.
The Committee of the Privy Council have had under consideration a report from the Superintendent General of Indian Affairs, dated 16th May, 1914, representing that it being necessary to erect a new school house on the Cape Croker reserve in the Province of Ontario, tenders were called for the construction of the building, receivable up to noon of the 4th May, 1914.

The Minister states that only one tender was received, being that of Messrs. Gilpin Bros., of Wiarton, for $5,700.00, who furnished the required security deposit equal to 10% of the contract price, his estimate for the construction of the building being $5,800.00.

The Minister recommends, pursuant to the requirements of sub-section 2 of section 36 of the Public Works Act, that the contract be awarded to Messrs. Gilpin Bros., for the amount of their tender, $5,700.00 the Architect of the Department of Indian Affairs having reported that this tender is fair and reasonable.

The Minister also recommends that authority be granted under the provisions of section 90 of the Indian Act, for the expenditure of the above sum being charged to the capital of the Cape Croker band, which amounts to $336,332.45, the necessary resolution of the Council.

The Honourable

The Superintendent General of Indian Affairs.
Council of the band having been received by the Department of Indian Affairs that the expenditure for the construction of this school be taken from their funds.

The Committee concur in the foregoing recommendations and submit the same for approval.

Clerk of the Privy Council.

Sir,

I have to acknowledge the receipt of your letter undated enclosing a list of supplies required to be furnished for the teacher's residence at the Port Elgin Indian Day School.

In reply I beg to say that a list of the various articles authorized is enclosed herewith. You should obtain competitive prices from a number of dealers handling these supplies and purchase from the one quoting you the lowest price. You should furnish the dealers with a copy of the enclosed list and obtain their prices. While all the articles should be serviceable, they should be as inexpensive as possible, and the Department will rely on you to see that no undue expenditure is occasioned in the supplying of these goods. You should attend to this matter at once, in order that these supplies can be delivered and the teacher's residence made as comfortable as possible. You can dispose of the mattress which is now being used by Mrs. Keshig for the sum of $7.00 and forward this amount to the Department. The double iron bed, mattress and springs, also the blankets, comforters and pillows while durable, should be as inexpensive possible.

As soon as the articles authorized on the enclosed list have been delivered you will be good enough to furnish properly certified vouchers, in duplicate, covering the expenditure incurred, to which should be attached a list of the firms asked by you for a price and the prices quoted them.

Your obedient servant,

Mr. Garland has just shown me your letter sent to me thru him including Mr. J.M. Cools denial as to the kindness of me and his smallness. Putting the blame on one who had nothing to do with it viz. Mr. Garland.

He told me plainly in his reply that I was engaged for this school & I could move my supplies all over to here, but just to send his letter down as your dept. had somehow

Mrs. Moore heard it all read his letter too and as she alone here I'll have her sign this too to show you where the blame lies. He advised me to move over so I now look at my expense but all which with lost time combined makes me the loser of $292.18 up till last Saturday.

All Mr. Garland said or did was as Mr. McCool said viz. to set the day to open the school and this is all he said or did about it.

I wish none the blame to go on Mr. Gardland not as if he were friends but as right to right.

If you care to settle his thru & show me square address me to R.R. #4, Wiarhon.

Sincerely Yours,

Dear Sir,

In answer to your letter No. 8-3-5 of 29th I wish to state the following facts in order to hasten matters before the severe cold weather.

Mr. Garland thought it useless to deepen the well drilled here some time ago as it is seventy feet deep and water is alkaline. All wells in vicinity no matter what depth have proved the same. The people are using spring water almost without an exception. Last Friday I sent an order to Mr. Carl Jones to have the spring across the road (the sole source of water supply near) properly protected by cement enclosure. I am seeing Mr. Jones who is a thoroughly reliable gentleman.
found that this was the spring Dr. Weigall had condemned some time ago. He reported it to me on following day so he might not see the Agent for a few days to tell him Mr. Jones who is one of my close neighbors has lived here for years and knows conditions better than either the Agent or I. He thinks it would be a waste of money to attempt drilling another well; judging from former experiences there is another failing spring of first class water about eighty rods from school building which he suggests should be piped to building. He considers this the only solution to the problem. To engage Indians as carriers of water would be unsafe from sanitary point of view also very uncertain. It is unfortunate that Mr. Abraham did not view conditions here in this matter during his last visit to Cape Croker. Mr. Garland spoke of bringing him before he came.
Ottawa, December 9, 1920.

Madam,

I have to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 6th instant with reference to the water supply for the use of the Port Elgin Indian Day School.

In reply I beg to say that Mr. Agent Garland informs the Department that he does not consider it advisable to deepen the well on account of the alkali in the water. It would hardly be possible to prevent the Indians from using this spring and it is considered that, if there is a good flow of water, there would be no danger of contamination from the utensils used by the Indians in procuring water.

I have to request that in future you forward all communications regarding school matters through the office of the local Indian Agent, Mr. Garland.

Your obedient servant,

Chatham, Oct. 8, 1921.

Dear Sir:

While at Cape Croker recently Miss Timberman, teacher at the Fort Elgin School complained about the water at the school. I am enclosing herewith Dr. Wigle's certificate in regard to the water. This report was made after he had submitted a sample of the water from the well at the school. This report shows that the water in the well is not fit for drinking purposes. Miss Timberman states that she had to carry the water, for the use of the school and for her personal use, about one mile. She enclosed a map which I am also enclosing.

This map shows location of the school grounds and the drilled well, which is 95 ft. deep. The best water in the locality is obtained from the spring at Laurier Elliott's farm. This spring is never-failing and pure. It is approximately one-half mile from the school. The only solution that could be offered is to pipe the water to the school from this spring. There is a fall of something like 35 ft. between the spring and the school. This should not prove to be a very expensive undertaking and is the only solution that I know to this problem.

The cost of the pipe would be approximately $250. It would have to be laid below the surface of the ground, deep enough so that the frost would not freeze it. This would require a trench which would cost approximately $5 per rod for digging which would amount to approximately $100.

On my next visit to Cape Croker I will go more thoroughly into the scheme and ascertain the durability of this spring etc., and in the meantime you might write and say whether it will be worth while to make further investigations.

Yours truly,

J. D. McLean, Esq.,
Sect., Dept. of Ind. Aff.,
Ottawa, Ontario.

Dear Sir:

Please find enclosed bills for equipment for above school.

When you were last mentioned about the six new shades for class rooms to be purchased at $5 each I could not get them less than 75 at Eaton's Match Walls in buff newly decorated. I used three shades by doubling each & using 3 of the old rolls, thereby making half the quantity do. The brass rods to go with should go with the equipment.

Just use your own judgment about returning for those as I can make use of them perhaps again elsewhere.
In regard to The Toilet Set, you spoke of my place of buying a new set which would cost much more than $3.00. I bought a new pitcher & match an old set which was here. Pitcher evidently broken or stolen. Charges were $0.25 express.

I was much disappointed you were unable to attend our Community Concert March 24. Our Band and Orchestra were out in full numbers and the music was splendid. We had just on program for an address but hope at once future time you may find it convenient to attend. I am grateful to know that this work is apparently replacing the drunken frequent debauches which took place previously. To me it seems a crime to suppress the musical talent so marked in these people. Much good can be accomplished through this medium.
The last from Nelson while I was there is at Cape Croker. It is addressed to Mr. Gibb who was leaving before I saw him in time to forward it. However, I can't say about it when a new agent takes charge.

Thanking you for the attention given the school during your short stay.

I am

Yours respectfully,

May Zimmerman.

I am inclosing a requisition form for school books etc required at once for this school and also for some repairs needed at the school. Ottawa, January 13, 1925.

Sir:

I have your letter of the 8th inst., informing the Department that Miss Cecil Lett has taken up duties as teacher at the Port Elgin Indian Day School, and enclosing a requisition for school supplies.

The Department does not pay any part of the cost of a teacher's expenses in proceeding to a school, and it is therefore regretted that we will be unable to pay the cost of the livery engaged in taking Miss Lett's baggage from Warton to the school, and she should arrange to make payment of the amount charged for the purpose.

An order is today being sent to the Government Stationery Office to forward to your address the classroom supplies considered necessary, with the exception of the 16 slates, medium, and the pointer. You may arrange for the purchase and delivery of the slates, and it may be possible for you to have a suitable pointer made to meet the requirements.

You should arrange to have suitable locks, with keys, placed on any of the doors requiring same. We note that you have already had a new lock placed on the basement door.

You may engage the services of a mechanic to have the repairs required made to the kitchen sink and waste pipe and also in putting a new damper in the furnace. You should arrange for the purchase of any material required for the above purpose. You may also arrange to have safety fasteners installed on the cellar windows, and you may purchase the pane of glass, 6 galvanized cups, 8 spoons, inexpensive, 3 each plates, cups and saucers, 2 window blinds of the size required, 1 bushel peas and 4 pounds of pork asked for.

Properly certified vouchers, in duplicate, should be forwarded covering the above authorized purchases, as well as for the repairs, etc., which you find it necessary to make in order to place the school in a comfortable condition.

Regarding the sand table which the teacher requires for the younger children, I shall be pleased if you will state whether you could arrange to have a suitable table made, and, if so, the approximate cost of the same.

We are anxious to make conditions as comfortable as possible for the new teacher, and I shall be pleased if you will arrange to have the new locks and other repairs attended to at an early date.

Your obedient servant,

Sir,

I beg to inclose Requisition for School Material forms for the three Schools on this Reserve, these forms being somewhat delayed owing to the teacher of Sidney Bay forgetting to send in her requisition.

I am also inclosing a form on which the teacher of Port Elgin School has made known a few of the needs of that School and in which she states that the stock of reading Books is depleted and gives a list of those needed to complete the Library and I would request that these be sent, as I personally know there are very few books at the School at present.

Her further note that a Piano is needed I would not recommend the purchase of, an account of the expenditure and cost involved in purchase, as I am of the opinion that the results would not justify the cost of a Piano and a small Organ would suit the purpose as well for teaching purposes and instruction and would recommend the purchase of an organ, if it could be secured reasonably.

A telephone is much needed in Port Elgin section of the Reserve, either at the School or a home near the School, for use of the teacher and the people in cases of sickness etc., as there is none within four miles of the School and not on the Reserve. If a Phone was installed, it could be put on the pay system, and a small fee charged to pay for itself and could be put in the School or Mrs Edward Keeshig's (which are central) and I would request consideration be given to this need.

Secretary,
Dept of Ind. Affs.
Ottawa.

Your obedient servant,

Indian Agent,
July 24th, 1925.

Sir:

I have your letter of the 21st instant enclosing requisition for school material for the three schools on the Cape Croker Reserve. Regarding the requisition, you will be further advised in a separate communication.

With reference to the request made for the supplying of a piano or a small organ for the use of the Fort Elgin Indian Day School, I beg to say that the Department does not supply equipment of this nature to Day Schools. We regret that it will be impossible to supply either of these instruments for this school.

With reference to your request that a telephone be installed for the use of the school and people residing on Fort Elgin section of the Reserve, I may say that so far as the school is concerned we do not provide telephone service. However, I will be pleased to have a report from you stating the distance which would be necessary from the nearest service to extend the line to Fort Elgin, also the approximate cost involved in putting up the line including posts, wire and so forth, the phone to be installed in a residence at a convenient centre. If the providing of phone service is approved the cost of same would have to be provided by the Band from their funds. After you have ascertained the cost involved you may refer the matter to the Band in Council and if they wish to have a phone service they should pass a resolution to provide the cost from their funds. When we have full information as to the cost and so forth as requested above consideration will be given to the matter.

Your obedient servant,

A.D. Moore, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Cape Croker, Ont.

Sir:

There has been a request received by me from the teacher of Port Elgin school to have manual training benches installed in that school and a request from Sidney Bay school for music to be taught there and I am of the opinion these schools are not far enough advanced in their ordinary school subjects to have any time to spare to take up any more studies such as these and as far as I can find out no child has passed from these two schools to High School for over 15 years and it shows that they need all their time on ordinary studies. Kindly give me your opinion on this subject.

Your obedient servant,

A. D. Moore.

Sir,

Motion #2 of June meeting of Cape Croker Band in Council was passed as follows,

Moved by Oliver Johnston sec by Wm Elliott that this Council recommends that the old School house at Port Elgin be made a charge of the United Church of Canada but that no other Societies, Lodges, Band etc shall be refused use of this building, upon request to the caretaker appointed by the Church and who shall keep the key to the building.

Note. This building is Band property and a couple of years ago was overhauled and repaired by the Band and the people have destroyed the locks and Windows and the building is now open to the elements and the Band is not prepared to spend any more on its repair. The United Church is agreeable to keep this building in repair and under the care of a caretaker if they are privileged to use it for a place of worship on alternate Sundays and I would recommend that this be done or that the building be sold outright to some responsible party.

Sir,

With further reference to Council motion of June 1926 and your answer of June 14th, file No 3-3-5, with reference to the placing of what is known as the old school house at Port Elgin section of this reserve under the control of the United Church, who agreed to keep the building in repair in return for its use, I would beg to inform you that a very delicate situation has arisen and I would wish the Department's decision in the matter.

Rev. O.B. Strapp, missionary of the United Church has complained to me about the building being used by an Indian known as Doc Crowell of Saugeen for religious meetings and he has forbidden this, but the Indian still uses the building and refuses to discontinue and I will try and give the facts as I can secure them of the trouble from the start.

"Doc" Crowell, for years was an officer of the Methodist Church and as such conducted meetings around the Country until he was deprived of his office. After that he joined the Anglican Church and as an Lay Reader conducted services for them and came at different times to Cape Croker at the request of the Anglicans to preach to them and always used a private dwelling for the purpose. His office in the Anglican Church terminated in the Summer of 1926, and at the present time he claims he is an Lutheran and as such is coming to this Reserve to preach, although according to Mr. Strapp he is not recognized by that body. He has always conducted himself right and I have not heard any complaints of his conduct while on this Reserve.

There is considerable discontent with Mr. Strapp among the Indians of his congregation and they claim that he is neglecting his people and not giving the attention that he should by not visiting his people when they are sick and that he is always away when wanted and that he preaches in words and
language that they cannot understand and there is some truth in that, that some of his sermons are a little too deep for the average Indian and a goodly number of them in the Protestant Church cannot understand English well and according to facts I can find they very much desire a change and I have come to the conclusion that they will not be satisfied until they get it and that they will be split into factions if they continue as they are.

The whole trouble comes from the fact that some of the officers in charge of the United Church, although attending their own services in the mornings request that Doc Crowell preach to them in the afternoons and evenings and order that he use their buildings for that purpose, which has caused Mr. Strapp to come to me to have him forbidden to do that and to be kept off the Reserve.

As these are religious matters I have in the past refrained in mixing in them and have always left the Churches look after their own businesses and work out their own salvations and as Mr. Strapp has come to me with his complaint I would wish the Dept's ruling on this question. According to the Council's motion other gatherings were allowed and could not be forbidden and the whole question rests on whether the Elders and officers of a Church have control over their own Church or has the Missionary? Has the Dept any evidence that Crowell is an undesirable man to be preaching? If the Indians want him to preach to them, can they be stopped using their own Churches? If an Indian conducts himself properly, would an Agent be doing right in ordering him off the Reserve?

As I have forbidden Crowell using these buildings, until I have your answer, I would request that your early attention be given.

Secretary.

Dept of Ind. Affs.
Ottawa.

Your obedient servant,

Indian Agent.
April 19, 1927.

Sir:

I beg to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 9th instant, regarding the presence of an Indian known as Doc Crowell, who persists in conducting religious meetings in the old Port Elgin school house.

In this connection I beg to refer you to my letter of the 24th of June last, in which you were advised that the Rev. Mr. Strapp might be assured that the United Church would be given undisputed possession of this old school house and would not be deprived of the privilege without good and sufficient cause.

As it would appear from your letter that the Rev. Mr. Strapp is not in good favour with some of the Indians under his care, the only thing I can suggest is that they petition the Mission Board of the United Church of Canada to replace him with a man that will be more suitable to their requirements.

I may add that it is considered in the best interest of all concerned that the Indian Doc Crowell should not be allowed to use the building in question. I find that the Indian Agent at Chippewa Hill had difficulty with this man Crowell and I enclose copy of a letter that was sent to that Agent on the 4th of August last.

Your obedient servant,

J.D. McLean,
Assistant Deputy and Secretary.

Dear Sir,

Our Chief informed me that the Council has passed a resolution to put an organ in each of the three schools and he hoped the Indian Dept. would approve the decision.

I thought a word from an old timer might help & gain a favorable answer.
As I lay here, knowing as I do by experience what a help a musical instrument is in a class room especially in these isolated Indian schools, also knowing the beneficial influence music has on the Indian child, I sincerely hope the organs will be purchased and installed in each school as soon as possible. Moreover an organ properly cared for will last for years, so the investment will be a good one.

There are several moderately priced organs manufactured, such as the portable organ which would be quite suitable for small schools, also the school organ, larger than the portable but which would answer all purposes in larger schools.

Everything seems to be going on nicely at the Cape even if we have an unusual number of stormy days. The men are cutting pulp wood, some have begun orchids, all seem to be busy.

Thanking you for your kind interest in this little corner of the world.

Yours, Yours with respect,

Mary Moffitt
Sir,

I beg to report Motion No 4, passed by the Cape Croker Band in Council at their regular meeting held here on March 5th,

Moved by Peter Nadjwon, sec by Alex Johnston, that we requisition the Dept of Indian Affairs for a sum of money with which to purchase three organs, one for each of the Schools on Cape Croker Reserve, the money to be taken from our Band funds.

Carried.

Note.-

I drew this matter to the attention of the Dept in 1925, at which time the School teachers requested that they be provided with either piano's or organs and it was stated at that time that no funds were available for such purchases and the matter was dropped. Since then Miss Moffitt's organ at her School has gone bad and is not fit for use and as it was her own property, it cannot be expected that she would replace it herself and thus the teaching of music has been at a disadvantage. Miss Lett at Port Elgin School also is a good musician and could no doubt use an organ to good advantage and thereby benefit that section. Miss McGarvey at Sidney Bay, while not herself musical, has always had trouble getting an instrument for Xmas concerts or gatherings and no doubt it could be used to good advantage. As the Council is prepared to pay the cost and which should not exceed $100.00 for the three organs, I would recommend their purchase.

Secretary.

Your obedient servant,

Indian Agent.
Ottawa, March 15, 1928.

Sir:

I have your letter of the 10th instant, relative to a resolution of the Cape Croker Band requesting that an organ be supplied to each of the schools on the Cape Croker Reserve and that the cost be taken from Band Funds.

In reply I beg to say it is not the policy of the Department to provide organs or pianos for Indian day schools. It is considered that, upon the occasion of a concert or other entertainment at the school, there would, no doubt, be some Indian home that would be able to supply the musical instrument, or arrangements could be made to rent one for the occasion. We do not care to expend Band Funds in the purchase of musical instruments of the kind required. Please advise Miss Moffitt and other interested parties.

Your obedient servant,

Sir,

I beg to report motion No 2, passed by the Cape Croker Band in Council at their regular meeting held here on April 2nd.

Moved by Peter Nadjiwon, seconded by Jonah Chegahno, that respecting the Department's endeavors to restrict the expenditures of our money, we again recommend that three organs at a total expense not to exceed $100 be purchased for our Reserve Schools as we recognize the great benefit derived by our children learning music.

Carried.

Note. I informed the Council of your decision to their previous motion at March meeting and they are not satisfied and have again passed the above motion for a reconsideration by you. The Council maintain and I also that the three organs can be secured for $100.00 and as stated in your letter an organ can be hired for concerts etc. at the School; this can no doubt be done but as it takes considerable time previous to practice for concerts and as an organ cannot always be secured without some expense it would lead me to believe that one purchased would not cost much more in the long run and would be there when needed. The teacher at Sidney Bay has a rented organ there which has always been used, Miss Moffatt has always had her own (now of no use) and the teacher at Port Elgin always has had trouble procuring one when needed. The part of the motion referring to the benefit derived from the children learning music, has reference to the fact that Miss Moffatt has for years taught the children to play both an organ and stringed instruments and has given a lot of her time out of school hours for this purpose as well as used her own organ for that long period and no doubt a lot of credit is due her that this Reserve can boast of a large number of good...
good musicians who received their musical start from her early assistance.

The Council takes the attitude that they have for years received the benefit of her instrument and that the least they can do is replace it by another either as a complete gift or for her use at the School.

I would request that you give this your consideration and cannot the rental derived from Sidney Bay pasture be used for this purpose the same as it was done for the purchase of the Council Hall piano?

Ottawa, August 13th, 1928.

Sir,

I have your letter of the 7th instant, with reference to the repairs and painting required at the Sidney Bay and Port Elgin Indian Day Schools and stating, in detail, the work that is to be performed. In this connection it is noted that you have obtained quotations from two parties and that you have accepted the lowest quotation, that of C. E. Whicher, viz., $435 for the work at Sidney Bay and $269 for the work at Port Elgin. Your action in this matter is approved. It is noted that considerably more work has to be performed than was at first expected but it is hoped that all the work as mentioned by you at each of these schools will be finished before the schools re-open after the present summer holidays. You should see that the work is satisfactorily completed and that a good grade of material is used. It is understood that Mr. Whicher will supply all material and labour for the prices quoted. You should forward properly certified vouchers, in duplicate, covering the cost of the work for each school separately. These vouchers should state, in detail, the work performed at each school.

It is noted that you intend having the work required at the Cape Croker School carried out under your supervision, employing Indian labour, and that the furnace will be repaired later, after the teacher returns. You should keep all expenses in this regard as low as possible and forward accounts in duplicate, properly certified, covering the cost of material and labour.

Your obedient servant,

Sir,

I beg to enclose a requisition submitted by the teacher of No. 3, Fort Elgin School on this Reserve and believe everything asked for to be needed with the exception of the coal oil stove, which when free wood is supplied and plenty of it, there should be no reason for the oil stove, unless the teacher intends residing in the School during the Summer holiday months which are the warmest and which is her privilege to stay or go somewhere else if she desires.

The sanitary closet for the use of the teachers at Cape Croker Reserve Schools, I believe to be necessary, as the teachers having to use the same toilets as the Indians are liable to secure the vermin, to their discomfort and I have had experiences of this when giving Indians a lift in my car and also from the fact I have a child attending School on the Reserve. Failing to secure a sanitary toilet, a section of the present toilets should be partitioned off for the exclusive use of the teacher and their companions at each of the three Schools and I will again bring this to your attention near the coming Summer holidays when some interior decorating should be done in all the Schools of the Reserve.

Your obedient servant,

Indian Agent.
Ottawa, February 23rd, 1929.

Sir:

I have your letter of the 20th instant, enclosing a requisition from the teacher of the Fort Elgin Indian Day School.

In reply I beg to say that an order is being forwarded to the Government Stationery Office to send to the teacher's address the quantity of scribblers and coloured mounting paper asked for.

You may arrange for the purchase and delivery of the following:

- 1 snow shovel,
- 1 Gal. boiled oil (for school floors),
- 1 quart light oak stain,
- 1 varnish,
- 1 iron handle,
- 1 bread pan,
- 6 thimbles,
- 1 package needles.

After you have made the purchase of these supplies, you should forward an itemized account, in duplicate, properly certified, covering the cost.

The Department is not prepared to supply a coal oil stove or a scythe.

Relative to the providing of a sanitary closet for the teacher's residence, I beg to say that you should bring this matter to the attention of the Department before the summer holidays, next, at which time, if you recommend that sanitary closets or separate closets be provided for the teachers in the schools on the Cape Croker Reserve, you should furnish full information as to the cost of any type of closet which you would recommend be supplied, when the matter will receive consideration.

Any interior redecorating required in the schools, together with the cost of same, should be given when you are reporting regarding the closets. If it is decided to have this work done, it should be carried out during the summer holidays.

Your obedient servant,

Dear Sir,

I know you will pardon me for writing to you again but I just received a letter from Miss Madjivan. When she was accepted for Cape Croker School she asked to correspond with me as she wanted to profit by my experience.

She tells me Mr. Poole has taken the Manual Training class from Cape Croker School & Port Elgin School. I was sorry to hear of this action as the decks...
were purchased in Cape Croker School over sixteen years ago and have been in constant use ever since. There were only six desks and none can be spared, as the number of boys working at the same time average from 8 to 10 and two boys cannot work at the same desk unless they are beginners and even then they are working under difficulties.

I cannot understand why Mr. Poste who knew so little about school work initiation taking equipment that we in use from another School. Another evidently he is keeping up the traditions of some of his predecessors whom the success at Cape Croker School was an eye-sore and who would have done something he has done & Miss R.

had I like her been a beginner. Aga had taught me to let them talk. It seems Miss Macgillivray will have to learn that also.

I shall enclose Miss Macgillivray letter so you may see the activities of the School. Of course I have not told her of your letter. Prefer to know more before doing so. It seems to me the same old spirit of bigotry and prejudice is at work. Mr. McKenzie had some samples of 30 years ago. Dear so much of it last year that I am inclined to suspect its presence in these recent occurrences.

With respect I am

Yours sincerely,

Mary Moffitt
Ottawa, November 8, 1929.

Madam:

I have your letter of the 7th instant, relative to the removal of one of the manual training benches from the Cape Croker School to the Port Elgin School.

In this connection I have to say that this action was taken on the recommendation of Mr. Conley, an officer of this Department, who recently visited the Cape Croker Reserve. He states that he discussed this matter with Miss Nadjiwan and she informed him that as all the manual training benches were not being used one could be spared. Mr. Agent Poste was, therefore, instructed to arrange for the transfer of a bench to Port Elgin, and, in doing so, he was simply carrying out instructions which he received from the Department. Should any necessity arise at the Cape Croker School, the bench could be returned or a new bench supplied.

Your obedient servant,

Russell T. Ferrier,
Supt. of Indian Education.

Miss Mary Moffitt,
1074 St. Hubert St.,
Montreal, P.Q.

Port Elgin Indian Day School:

Ottawa, June 6th, 1930.

Sir,

Mr. Inspector McGookin, who recently visited the Port Elgin Indian Day School, states that the following repairs are required to the school building and teacher's residence:

"New covers on the seats of both closets are needed.

"Screens in front of both closets need to be straightened and some boards replaced.

"The water pipes from the eavestroughing have become disconnected and require attention.

"The interior of the teacher's residence is badly in need of decorating and the plaster in places will have to be repaired both upstairs and down. The kitchen and living room should be decorated and the woodwork painted during the summer. The upstairs portion could wait until next year.

"The ceiling of the classroom and the walls of the girls' cloakroom are quite dirty-looking and, if possible, should be painted this summer.

I have to request that you will arrange to have new covers placed on the seats of both closets and the screens in front of both closets straightened and any boards required replaced. You may also arrange to have the water pipes from the eavestroughing repaired and placed in good condition. Any expense in connection with this work should be kept as low as possible and, when completed, you should forward a properly certified account, in duplicate, covering the cost.

Relative to the repairs and redecorating required to the interior of the teacher's residence, also the painting of the ceiling of the classroom and the walls of the girls' cloakroom, I have to request that you will furnish a report giving an estimate of the cost of having this work carried out. You should state definitely what work you would have done undertaken and how you would propose having it carried out. Provided the cost for the purpose is not large and funds can be provided, authority will be granted for you to have this work done during the coming summer holidays. Your early reply, giving the information requested, will be appreciated.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Acting Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

Postel, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Cape Croker, Ont.

Sir:-

I beg to submit report on Port Elgin Indian Day School, No 3, as requested in your letter No 8-3-5, dated June 6th, inst., regarding repairs, and re-decoration of same.

The interior of the teachers residence is in need of re-decoration, etc. (the kitchen and living-room.)

Sir:

I beg to report to you regarding the furnace of No. 3, Port Elgin School, on Cape Croker Reserve.

I made my monthly school inspection on the 28th inst., and found the heating apparatus, in a very faulty condition. We are experiencing cold and snowy weather, and the class room in this school was very cold, in spite of a good fire having been built in the furnace. Consequently, I spent considerable time endeavouring to find the cause of the trouble, but without success.

In my opinion, the furnace should be thoroughly overhauled by a capable man, whom I could procure from the Hunter Hardware Co., Wiarton, and the work would have to be done on a Saturday, while the pupils were out of school.

Sir:

Mr. Inspector McCookin, in a report on his recent visit to the Port Elgin Indian Day School, states that the closet screens need repairing and that the windows in the boys' closet and in the cellar of the school building need replacing. You will be good enough to arrange at an early date to have the repairs carried out to the closet screens and any broken glass replaced. All costs for the purpose should be kept as low as possible and, when completed, an account, in duplicate, properly certified, should be forwarded covering the expenditure.

The Inspector has reported regarding punishment administered by the teacher, Mrs. Bell, and complaints made to him by certain of the parents. It is stated that Mrs. Bell made some of the pupils take soap into their mouths as a punishment and, as a consequence, they became sick. You will be good enough to instruct Mrs. Bell that this punishment is to cease, and that, under no circumstances, must she continue the soap method of punishment. The only complaint was regarding her method of punishment, as mentioned above.

The Department is ordering four of Nelson's Pictures of Canadian History. They will be sent addressed to the teacher, and she should see that they are hung on the walls in the classroom.

The labour required, I estimate would cost in the neighbourhood of two dollars. It would be impossible to make a satisfactory job during present wintry conditions, but if the Department approves of it, I will have this work done whenever weather conditions will permit.

Secretary,

The seats in the boys' water closets

Ottawa, June 30, 1934.

Sir:

In connection with the report of Inspector J. M. Game on his inspection of the Port Elgin Indian Day School, he states as follows:

"The seats in the boys' water closets are still filthy, largely because there is no urinal (a relatively small expenditure)."

Ottawa, July 9, 1935.

Sir:

I have to acknowledge receipt of the requisition which you forwarded, from the teacher of the Port Elgin Indian Day School, for supplies for the pupils' midday meal and equipment for teacher's living quarters.

In reply I have to say that, when the school re-opens after the summer holidays, you may arrange for the purchase and delivery of the following:

10 lbs. cocoa, 25 lbs. condensed milk,
25 " sugar, 15 " peas,
15 " beans, 15 " pork.

You may also purchase 5 yards linen towelling, 2 quarts floor paint, and one broom. Please obtain itemized accounts, in triplicate, covering the cost. These, you should attach to proper voucher forms, certify in the usual manner and forward for payment.

Regarding the teacher's request for one set of bed springs and a mattress, please state the approximate cost of this equipment and report concerning the necessity for supplying same.

The teacher has requested that a culvert be installed over the ditch in front of large gate. You should advise the Department regarding the necessity and give an estimate of the cost.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. Mackenzie,
Secretary.

A. C. Poste, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
R. #5, Wiarton, Ont.
Sir:

I beg to acknowledge the receipt of your letter No. 3-1-5, dated July 9th, inst., regarding the requisition of the teacher of the Port Elgin Indian Day School on the Cape Croker Reserve, and note is made of those items authorized to be purchased for this school.

Regarding the request of the Teacher, for one set of bed springs, and a mattress, I beg to report to the Department that the old ones are now worn out, and can be replaced at a cost of around the sum of $16.00., this to include the springs and the mattress.

I have noted the request of Mrs Bell that a culvert be installed over the ditch in front of the large gate at the school. At the present time, I beg to state this appears to be unnecessary, but when it is necessary to have this done, this portion of road will be graded, and a culvert installed, as part of the road-work system here, and will be paid for from the road-work.

The Secretary,

Dept. of Ind. Affs.

Ottawa.

Your obedient servant,

Indian agent.

Sir:

I note your report regarding the request of the teacher that a culvert be installed over the ditch in front of the large gate at the school and that you consider it unnecessary to have this work done at the present time.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,

EXTRACT FROM REPORT OF INSPECTOR J. M. GAME ON HIS INSPECTION OF THE PORT ELGIN INDIAN DAY SCHOOL.

Date of Inspection Nov. 27, 1935.

A complete new set of eave troughing is urgently required. The school steps are in a dilapidated condition and the interior of the classroom should be redecorated. White ceilings and cream or buff walls are recommended in the Ontario Regulations. The paths leading to the water closets are veritable quagmires in places. Fine gravel placed in the low spots would eliminate this condition. Boards are off the fence used as a screen in front of the girls' water closet. This fence should be rebuilt. The pump in the residence requires repairs - very probably new leaters in the valves.
Ottawa, December 14, 1935.

Dear Sir,-

In a report regarding his recent inspection of the Port Elgin Indian Day School, Inspector Game states:

"The school steps are in a dilapidated condition.
"Boards are off the fence used as a screen in front of the girls' toilet.
"The pump in the residence requires repairs."

The above matters should receive your early attention.

Yours truly,

A. F. MacKenzie.
Secretary.

Indian Agent,

******DATE OF INSPECTION MAY 12th, 1936.

There are some broken window panes in the school and the seats are dirty. While the holes at the entrances to the water closets have been filled with gravel there are low places along the paths leading to these places which should be similarly treated.
Ottawa, May 22nd, 1936.

Dear Sir,-

With reference to his inspection of the Port Elgin Indian Day School on the 12th instant, Inspector Game writes:

"There are some broken window panes in the school and the seats are dirty. While the holes at the entrances to the water closets have been filled with gravel, there are low places along the paths leading to these places which should be similarly treated."

You should have the necessary new window panes installed and the janitor should clean the seats.

No doubt, you can arrange to have some gravel placed around the entrance to the toilets. This should not involve any heavy expense.

Yours truly,

Dear Sir:

The Department finds it necessary to return for further explanation the vouchers which you submitted in connection with the painting of the Port Elgin Indian day school.

Voucher 66 covers the cost of paint, varnish etc. and you quote as authority official letter of March 6. This only authorized purchase of 12 gallons of paint. Sir:

I beg to acknowledge Departmental letter of May 8th, re vouchers submitted in connection with painting of Port Elgin Indian Day School.

In regards to voucher 66 it was necessary to purchase glue to gluesize the walls before the paint was put on. The turpentine was needed to thin the paint which I forgot to estimate when I sent in requisition for paint.

In regards to paint brushes, I ask the C. E. Whicher Company to furnish good brushes and these were the ones that were sent, I did not realize that they were costing so much. I am sorry that this occurred and I will try and keep the expenditure down according to Departments authority hereafter. I have these brushes in my care and they can be used in future when required.

I beg to report, when I requisitioned for the paint for Port Elgin School I asked if it could be painted at Easter Holidays. I received word about the paint but not about engaging anyone to do the work. I waited for further word from the Department about engaging a man to do the work and when I did not receive word I engaged Mr. Hambly as he has always done such work on the Reserve., hoping it would be satisfactory to the Department.

I have had Mr. Hambly get receipts from the help he had employed showing that they received payment for their labor. Alvin and Raymond Hambly employed as shown on voucher are the sons of Mr. W. C. Hambly and they work together on such jobs.

I trust I have explained this satisfactory.

Ottawa,
August 25, 1939.

Dear Sir:

Miss Gladys R. Parks, teacher of the Port Elgin No. 3 Indian day school, requests that she be supplied with 1 manual training table and 12 large size adjustable desks.

I am anxious to know if the manual training table to which she refers is a table or if it is a bench ordinarily used for manual training projects. If so, could this bench be made locally? I am anxious to have also an exact description of the desks and the type of desk now in use at the school. You might explain what the teacher means by adjustable desks.

Your immediate attention to this matter will be very much appreciated.

Yours truly,

R. A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

F.W. Tuffnell, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
R.R. #5,
Wiarton, Ont.
Sir;

I beg to reply to Departmental letter of August 25th in regards to desks and manual training bench for No.3 Port Elgin school.

I have to inform you that the manual training table referred to in Department letter is a bench ordinarily used for manual training projects, I have made enquires and find this bench can not be made locally.

As to the 12 large size adjustable desks, Miss Parke has given me the No.'s of desks which are as follows No.1.C.O.& S.F.Company Limited? Preston, Ontario.

What Miss Parke means by adjustable desks are the type which can be adjusted to suit a small or larger pupil.

The type of desk now in use are the ordinary school desk which are used in all day schools.

Trusting this is the information required by the Department.

Your obedient servant,

The Secretary
Indian Affairs Branch
Dept of Mines & Resources
Ottawa.

Ottawa, July 6, 1943.

Mr. F. W. Tuffnell, Indian Agent, R. #5, Wiarton, Ont.

I have your requisition of the 30th ultimo, regarding repairs to the woodshed roof, porch steps, gates, window sash and windows of the Port Elgin Indian Day School and residence.

When submitting such requests, you should always give the Department an estimate of the cost of carrying out the work. In this particular case, I presume that the expenditure will not be heavy, and you may therefore arrange to have the necessary work done before the school re-opens on September 1.

R. A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.
I am in receipt of Department letter of June 28th regarding requisition from teacher of Fort Elgin Indian Day School.

I wish to advise the Department that Miss Parke informs me that the furnace does not heat the class room satisfactory. I will have to get a man up from Wiarton who understands furnaces to inspect it probably new flues are required.

The wood shed needs shingling also has pulled away from the main part of the building letting the rain and snow drift in this will have to be repaired.

I would estimate the approximate cost at about $125.00 for material and labour and would be pleased to be advised at the Department's earliest convenience if this work could be undertaking.

Indian Affairs Branch
Dept of Mines & Resources
Ottawa.

R. A. Hoey,

July 27, 1943.

I have for acknowledgment Department letter of July 8th regarding the estimate cost of material for making repairs to Port Elgin Indian Day School.

I have had C.E.Whicher, Ltd estimate the cost of material required for the necessary repairs and enclose copy of material required total cost delivered would be approximately $104.27

The labour required would be approximately $100.00 I would try to get Indian labour but men are very scarce on the reserve at the present time.

When I looked this school over I found it was really in bad need of repairs and if the Inspector of Agency's could look this job over I am quite sure he would recommend that the work be done at once in order to save further costs. If this is approved I would be pleased to be advised at the Department's earliest convenience.

Indian Affs Branch
Dept of Mines & Resources
Ottawa.

Accommodations should be improved in the following respects:

Ottawa,
May 12, 1944.

Mr. F.W. Tuffnell, Indian Agent, R.R. #5, Wiarton, Ont.

In reporting on his inspection of the Port Elgin School Inspector Game recommends:

1. Thoroughly scrub boys' water closet as the seats are filthy.

2. Make further effort to procure the services of a caretaker.

You should arrange for the immediate cleaning of the toilets. The Department cannot understand why it is necessary for the Inspector to bring this to our attention. I presume that you visit the school regularly and you should always see that the toilets are kept clean.

The Inspector also recommends painting the exterior of the school and decorating the interior of the classroom. You might let me know the approximate cost of these and a decision will then be made if funds are available.

R.A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.
I have for acknowledgment Department letter of May 12th with reference to Inspector Game reporting on Sidney Bay and Port Elgin Day schools.

I have had the toilets cleaned at both schools; these are cleaned quite often but the children are not very clean in their habits with the results the toilets are not always as clean as they should be.

Before I would recommend the painting of Port Elgin school I have to suggest that a new furnace is required as the old one smokes so badly that the teacher says it is impossible to teach at times, also it does not heat the classroom properly, the flues and grates are all burned out.

The approximate cost to have a new furnace installed would be approximately $250.00. I had the classroom decorated five years ago but due to the furnace smoking so much the walls are in a very dirty condition now again.

I would be pleased to be advised by the Department as soon as possible if a new furnace could be installed.

Indian Affairs Branch
Dept of Mines & Resources
Ottawa.

Indian Agent

EXTRACT FROM REPORT OF J. M. GAME, SCHOOL INSPECTOR,
- dated March 25, 1946 - on PORT ELGIN INDIAN DAY SCHOOL

The accommodations and the condition of the school in general are disgraceful. Many windows inside and outside are broken. Shattered glass litters the boys' toilet. Each window has on it scores of live house flies and many scores of dead flies lie on the window sills. Cupboards, desks, floors and desks are untidy. The girls' toilet is untidy and has a broken partition. Eave troughing and conductor pipes are broken or missing. Litter is scattered over the yard.

The conditions enumerated above are largely because of the inability of the teacher to manage and control her pupils. It is fortunate for the section that a change is being made at Easter. There is little point in reglazing window panes, etc., until the Easter Vacation.
Ottawa, April 16, 1946.

Mr. F. W. Tuffnell, Indian Agent,
R. R. #5, Wiarton, Ontario.

In reporting on his inspection of the Port Elgin Indian Day School on March 25, Inspector Game writes as follows:

"The accommodations and the condition of the school in general are disgraceful. Many windows inside and outside are broken. Shattered glass litters the boys' toilet. Each window has on it scores of live house flies and many scores of dead flies lie on the window sills. Cupboards, desks, floors and desks are untidy. The girls' toilet is untidy and has a broken partition. Eave troughing and conductor pipes are broken or missing. Litter is scattered over the yard."

In view of the fact that you are expected to visit the day schools in your agency regularly, it is difficult for us to understand why the above conditions did not receive your attention and thereby make it unnecessary for the Public School Inspector, who makes only one visit a year, to bring the matters to our attention.

The Department will expect you to make the repairs and improvements required at this school during the Easter holidays, so that it may be in proper condition when the new teacher opens the school after the holidays.

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.

Sir,

I have the honor to acknowledge receipt of your letter No. 152191-1 dated 4th inst., and in reply I beg to say, the only reason given by the Council for passing resolution No. 4, is that Mr. Lawrence doesn't teach knitting and sewing to the pupils. While this excuse is made, the real cause is that he has had to discipline several of the boys and, among them, the son of the mover of this resolution, Alfred Stinson. He is a large boy about fifteen years old, he and his father came to me complaining that Mr. Lawrence had expelled him for a week from school. I at once went to the school and enquired into the facts and found that his conduct was disgraceful and his influence most hurtful in the school. I told him he must make an apology to the teacher and he did so and went back to school. The mothers on the Rama Reserve are quite competent to teach their daughters knitting and sewing. I have watched the school at Rama closely for nineteen years and can say without hesitation, from the standpoint of general progress, discipline and attendance, it was never in as good condition as it is now.

To The Honorable Clifford Sifton
Minister of Interior,-Superintendent General of Indian Affairs et al

Dear Sir,

We the undersigned Officers and members of Rama Indian Mission of the Methodist Church of Canada, have the honor to present the following facts in reference to the above Mission, for your kind consideration.

The reverend John Lawrence has been our Pastor for the past (nearly) nine years, during that time many of our people, including former Officers of the Church, as well as Members of the Congregation have become dissatisfied and tired of his manner and methods, as well as of his preaching, and have severed their connection with the Church, joining the Salvation Army and other Organizations, to the detriment of the best interests of the Church and Mission, as well as of the people, and at the same time, the membership has decreased, while we are of the opinion that there ought to have been an increase thereof.

We are also of the opinion that, his attendance and attention to the School, of which he is also the Teacher, has not been as regular, or the results as great as they should have been, and the interests of the Mission, School and people have not progressed, but have suffered by his prolonged residency and Pastorate.

And we humbly pray that, you will take such action, or make such representations to the President of the Methodist Conference of the Methodist Church as may in your judgment appear wise, in order to secure a change in the Pastorate of our Mission, and Teaching of our School.

And Your Petitioners as in duty bound, will ever pray.

Sir,

Some time ago I received a communication from the Department enclosing copy of a Memorial which had been addressed to the Superintendent General by certain Indians of the Rama Band, expressing dissatisfaction with their Missionary and Teacher, the Rev John Lawrence, and requesting that steps be taken to secure a change. I sent a copy of the Memorial forward to the Rev J.J. Redditt of Barrie, Chairman of the ecclesiastical district in which the Rama Mission is situated, requesting him to enquire carefully into the case, and report his findings to me. Subsequently Mr Redditt reported as follows:

"This matter is wholly without foundation. The Public School Inspector states school never was in finer form. Mr Indian Agent McPhee reports all well, and Mr Lawrence doing well. One of the names attached (to the memorial) is not a Local preacher; no one venturing to move for a renewal of his license owing to bad conduct. Jealousy about the election of a new Chief the main cause. The losing faction thinking Mr Lawrence influenced against them. The fact is he maintained a discreet neutrality."

As Mr Redditt is a gentleman whose statements are thoroughly reliable, there would appear to be no ground for further action in this matter.

I have the honor to be, Sir,

The Honorable the Superintendent General of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.

Your Obedient Servant,

General Secretary.

In reply to your letter of the 21st instant, I would say that after giving the matter a great deal of thought I have come to the conclusion that the worst course for me to pursue under the circumstances is to resign my position as teacher of the Ram Reserve School.

When your Secretary, Mr. Ramsden, upon the occasion of his visit here informed me that he had received no instructions from the Department regarding this case, I was so surprised that I could not properly explain what had taken place or why there had been such a delay. But as the Indians had nothing to say and apparently had quieted down, I agreed with him that it was better to let the matter rest.

That the Indians do not intend to do so, however, is evidenced by the fact that during the week following Mr. Ramsden's visit because I was one minute after nine o'clock in teaching school, Alfred Simon, Jr., of the Board and Sam Snake, walked into the school room wrote on the blackboard:

"Teacher late."
Why they should keep up this sort of thing is more than I can say unless it is that they still erroneously believe that the members of my family are wholly responsible for the taking away of their child, and even go so far as to say that she caused her removal in order that she might be trained as a maid for my sister, who is about to be married.

These people have also circulated many statements detrimental to my reputation as a teacher. They have stated repeatedly that they are going to put me out at Midsummer, yet a teacher with papers. This, of course, I know they have not the power to do, but it only shows the attitude they have taken.

They have also had a good deal to say about the school being closed in February owing to my illness. This would not have occurred had the school been in proper repair.

All along the north side of the school room there is at least a space of from two to three inches between the floor and the wall. This with the broken window and the transom being loose, caused the school room to be very uncomfortable and in very wet weather almost impossible to keep warm.

I also several times after a long walk through the deep snow have reached the school room only to find it locked and sweat outside until the case takes arrived and put a fire and think the Department will agree with me that it is not well to insist that a holiday was required.
The principal work with this idea is that they are such an art around it that an opportunity presents itself; they will not come out into the open and say what they have to like men but will work and talk about you in a way that is difficult to get at and yet leads to destroy any little influence one may have. And if you do not lend them all the money they wish to cross them in any particular, they do not hesitate to tell the most absolute falsehood if they think by doing so they can injure you in any way. Men cannot fail to be certain of it at their mercy.

This Alfred Slavin told Mr. Graham, the agent, that he was absent from my school a week without leave and a fee—that this is a deliberate false tool can easily be proved.

All this talk, of course, has had its influence upon the children and this I feel may benefit them and anything else for no teacher who has not the cooperation and good will of the parents can hope to do effective work.

Here are some of the reasons why I think it better & worth doing.

Yours respectfully,

ONTARIO SUMMER MODEL SCHOOLS
1912

GENERAL REGULATIONS

LOCATION AND PURPOSE

1. (1) The Summer Model Schools are located at Bracebridge, Gore Bay, Ottawa, Port Arthur, and Sturgeon Falls.

(2) The purpose of these Schools is to prepare teachers for Temporary and Third Class certificates; the Schools at Ottawa and Sturgeon Falls, for certificates valid in English-French Schools, and those at Bracebridge, Gore Bay, and Port Arthur for certificates valid in the English Schools of the Districts.

CONDITIONS OF ADMISSION

2. The dates of opening, the conditions for admission, the provisions for teachers' Temporary and Third Class certificates, and the allowance to teachers-in-training in attendance for travelling expenses and board are set forth in detail in Circulars 30 and 31, which may be obtained on application to the Deputy Minister.

COURSES

3. There are two courses at each Summer Model School, the first for new teachers-in-training, and the second for those who have already taken the first course, or are holders of expired Third Class or District certificates. For details as to the certificates granted on such courses, see Circulars 30 and 31.

DUTIES OF PRINCIPAL

4. Subject to the Regulations and to the approval of the Minister of Education, the Principal of each Summer Model School shall prescribe the duties of his assistant and the teachers-in-training, and shall be responsible to the Minister for the efficiency of the school.
DUTIES OF TEACHERS-IN-TRAINING

5. (1) Teachers-in-training shall attend regularly and punctually, and shall submit to such discipline as the Principal may prescribe.

(2) Teachers-in-training who, in the opinion of the Principal, are unduly defective in scholarship or whose conduct or progress is unsatisfactory may be dismissed by the Principal at any time during the course from further attendance.

TEXT BOOKS

6. (1) For the First and the Second Course, teachers-in-training shall provide themselves with the following:

The Regulations and Course of Study of the Public Schools (free).

The Text-books prescribed for the Public Schools.

The Public School Manuals (15 cts. and 25 cts. each). Department of Education, Toronto.

The Readers in Geography (50 cts.), History (35 cts.), and Hygiene (25 cts.), recommended for Form III. The Copp, Clark Co., Toronto.

The Ontario Writing Course (5 cts.). E. H. Harcourt Co., Toronto.

Prang: Text-books of Art Education, 2nd (25 cts.), and 7th (55 cts.). The Geo. M. Hendry Co., Toronto.

Prang: A Course of Study in Art (25 cts.). The Geo. M. Hendry Co., Toronto.

Physical Exercises for the Public Elementary Schools (25 cts.), The Copp, Clark Co., Toronto.

Note.—Teachers of Roman Catholic Separate Schools may substitute the Canadian Catholic School Readers, The Copp, Clark Co., Toronto, for the Ontario Public School Readers.

(2) For the Second Course, teachers-in-training shall provide themselves with the following, in addition:

McMurray: The Method of the Recitation (75 cts.). The Macmillan Co. of Canada.

Gordy: Psychology ($1.25). The Copp, Clark Co., Toronto.

Tilley: Methods of Teaching ($1.50). The Macmillan Co. of Canada.

Millar: School Management ($1.00) William Briggs, Toronto.

Note.—The names of the publishers are given above. The books may, however, usually be obtained from a local bookseller.

RELATIVE IMPORTANCE OF SUBJECTS

7. From the point of view of class work:

(1) The following subjects are regarded as of prime importance:
   Educational Principles and General Methodology; School Organization and Management; Special Methodology in Language and Composition, Spelling, Literature, Grammar, History, Geography, Arithmetic, Writing, Reading;

(2) The following subjects are regarded as of secondary importance, as much class-instruction and direction being given as time will permit, and the responsibility for carrying on the course in each, with the aid of the text-book, devolving on the teacher-in-training:
   Physiology and Hygiene, Nature Study, Art Work, Physical Training, Music, School Law and Regulations.

NUMBER OF HOURS IN TIME-TABLE FOR EACH SUBJECT

8. The provision in the time-table for the subjects of each course shall be as follows, subject to modification in accordance with the conditions of each school, and, in the case of the second course, the proficiency of the teachers-in-training:
