9. After allowing for the enrolment and organization and the final examinations, the rest of the time for the course (about 26 hours) should be divided amongst the other subjects according to the conditions of the school and the capabilities of the staff.

Note.—Where practicable the subjects of the First and Second courses should be taken together, and probably, in most cases, half-hour lessons would be sufficient. Provision should be made for home exercises, including lesson plans.

TIME FOR EACH SUBJECT AT FINAL EXAMINATIONS

10. At the final written examinations, one and a half hours shall be allowed for each of the following: Educational Principles and General Methodology, School Organization and Management, Literature, Geography, Arithmetic, Reading, and Language and Composition.
CERTIFICATES: FIRST COURSE

11. Temporary certificates will be granted on the results of the examinations which shall be conducted by the staff at the close of the First Course, in accordance with the following scheme:

(1) A written examination, which will test both academic and professional knowledge, will be held on the following subjects, each having a maximum of 75 marks:

- Educational Principles and General Methodology, School Organization and Management, Special Methodology in:
  - Language and Composition, Literature, Geography, Arithmetic, and Reading.

(2) To the marks obtained in each of the foregoing subjects a maximum of 25 marks may be added for class and home exercises during the Session.

(3) For such of the following as are taken up during the Course, a maximum of 50 marks may be awarded on the class work and home exercises, and such other tests as the Principal may apply:

- Writing, History, Spelling, Grammar, Physiology and Hygiene, Nature Study, Art Work, Physical Training, Music, School Law and Regulations.

(4) Candidates shall be entitled to certificates who obtain 40 per cent. in each subject and 60 per cent. of the total of the subjects enumerated in (1) and (3) above respectively.

CERTIFICATES: SECOND COURSE

12. (1) (a) In 1912, Limited Third Class certificates will be granted on the results of the examinations, which shall be conducted by the staff at the close of the Second Course; after 1912, Temporary certificates will be granted on the results of the examinations, and these certificates will be valid until the next Model School final examination. Said certificates are valid as provided in 1 (2) above.

(b) The examinations at the close of the Second Course shall be held in accordance with the same scheme as that for the final examinations at the close of the First Course.

(2) After 1912, the holders of Temporary certificates obtained at the final examinations in the Second Course will be granted Limited Third Class certificates on the following conditions:

(a) They shall pass the final written examinations of the Model Schools in the following subjects, obtaining 40 per cent. in each subject and 60 per cent. of the aggregate.

Professional: Principles of Education, School Organization and Management, each 100.

Academic and Professional: Arithmetic, Literature, Grammar, History, Composition, Geography, Nature Study, each 100.

(b) The standing awarded such candidates at the final examinations of the Second Course of the Sumner Model Schools shall be accepted for the following subjects:

- Academic and Professional: Art, Music, Reading, Spelling, Writing, Physical Training, and Physiology and Hygiene, School Law and Regulations.

(c) Such candidates shall submit to the Minister a certificate from the last Inspector under whom they have served that they have taught successfully.

Note.—A Limited Third Class certificate does not entitle the holder to teach in any school until it has been endorsed by the Minister of Education as to the school that school. When a School Board wishes to employ a teacher with a First or Second Class certificate, the Minister may, on the recommendation of the Inspector concerned, validate a Limited Third Class certificate for the school in charge of said Board for a limited period. Before applying to School Boards, the holder of such certificate should consult the Inspector in regard to available vacancies.
SYLLABUS OF FIRST YEAR'S COURSE

1. EDUCATIONAL PRINCIPLES AND GENERAL METHODOLOGY

The object of the course is to provide the teachers-in-training with such an elementary working knowledge of the nature of educational principles and of general methodology as is practicable at this stage, and as will improve natural tact and skill by determining procedure and forming ideals.

The course embraces the following topics:

Methods of Instruction: The purposes of method; the necessity of basing methods of instruction on a knowledge of the characteristics and conditions of the learner.

Attention: Learning conditioned on the attention of the learner; non-voluntary and voluntary attention, conditions of each; attention in young children and in adults compared; methods of securing and retaining attention; obstacles to attention.

Apperception: Nature of apperception; necessity for making subjects taught meaningful; the process of interpreting the new in terms of the old applied to school studies; significance of the maxim, "Proceed from the known to the related unknown."

Retention: Conditions of retention; the relation of retention and apperception; the factors in efficient recall; functions of the drill lesson and of the review lesson; methods of conducting drills and reviews.

The Process of Learning: Learning a development from the vague to the definite, by a process of analysis and synthesis; typical illustrations of this principle from varied subjects.

Impression and Expression: Their interdependence; expression as a phase of method; the necessity and use of the expressive studies.

Methods of Lesson Presentation: Lecture method of presentation; text-book method of presentation; question and answer method of presentation, right and wrong methods of questioning, qualities of a good answer, treatment of faulty answers; mistakes in dealing with answers; graphic representation as a means of presentation, use of diagrams, pictures, maps, etc.; nature and functions of objective teaching, limitations of objective teaching.

Note.—The foregoing course should be taken up in a simple manner early in the session. Gordy's Psychology may be referred to.

2. SCHOOL ORGANIZATION AND MANAGEMENT

The object of the course is to provide the teachers-in-training with an elementary knowledge of the technique of school management and the organization of rural one-teacher schools.

The course embraces the following topics:

The Aims and Importance of School Management and Organization.

The Teacher: Qualifications of a good teacher; his relations with the inspector, trustees, pupils, parents, and the public; daily preparation of work; care of health.

The Problems of School Life: First day at school; school organization and its difficulties; promotions; school examinations; school records.

Discipline: Its meaning and aims; the forces that make for good discipline; value of games; physical exercise; punishments; incentives.

The Daily Programme: The construction of typical time-tables for rural schools; seat work; individual black-board work; reviews; and examinations.

Desirable School Habits: Punctuality, regularity, neatness in person and work; accuracy, promptness, quietness, industry, obedience; the relation of the preceding to moral training.

3. SCHOOL LAW AND REGULATIONS

The Ontario School Law and Regulations in so far as they deal with the duties and obligations of teachers and pupils. The following should be emphasized:

The importance of signing the name correctly and the Christian name in full, and of specifying in the case of females, whether Miss or Mrs.

The necessity of making all agreements clear and conclusive. These should be contracts as provided by the statute. Substituting for the contract an agreement made orally or by correspondence often leads to misunderstanding and difficulty. (P. S. Act, Section 85 and form of agreement.)

Note.—Every school register contains two copies of a form of agreement, one for the Teacher and one for the Board. Additional copies may be obtained on application to the Department.

Duties of teachers and Inspectors. The payments of the grants and of other matters directly affecting the teacher, trustees, and school. (P. S. Act, Sections 6, 7, 8, 9, 82, 84, 87, 99, 116; and Instructions 12, 13 and 14.)

The Public School Regulations.

Penalties and prohibitions regarding the buying and selling of textbooks and school supplies, and the use of unauthorized books and pamphlets. (Department of Education Act, Section 28; P. S. Act, Section 112, and Text-book Regulations, Circular 14.)

The Ontario Public Health Act and Regulations, so far as they pertain to teachers, pupils, and the school.
4. SPECIAL METHODOLOGY

The object of the course is to prepare the teacher-in-training for the intelligent application of the principles of education to the course in each subject of the Public School programme.

The course in each subject embraces the following topics:

(1) A general survey of the Public School course of study with a view to understanding the special object of each subject and the correlation of the different subjects amongst themselves.

(2) The systematic study of the subject matter of the Public School textbooks with emphasis on the elements; special methods of instruction with type lessons and other illustrations of the most important topics, including those detailed under each head below, so that the teacher may know how to use each textbook. The use of the natural method in each subject should be introduced by a few lessons of a general character, embracing the application of the principles of general method to the teaching of the subject.

NOTE.—A number of Manuals of Method in the subjects of the Public School course have been prepared. The Department of Education hopes to have the series complete at an early date.

(3) In the Ottawa and Sturgeon Falls Summer Model Schools for teachers of English-French Schools, the special methodology of teaching English to French-speaking pupils is provided for under Language and Composition below. For the methodology of French Reading and Grammar, no special provision is necessary. Notwithstanding the differences in the content of English and French Reading and Grammar, the methodology of the former may easily be adapted to the latter. In the case of Grammar, however, due to French etymology should be taken up in the language lessons of Form I, to account for the numerous inflections which must be assimilated early in order that the pupil may be able to write and spell even simple sentences.

NOTE.—A Manual of Method for teaching English to French-speaking pupils is now being prepared and, by next September, will be distributed amongst the English-French Schools of the Province.

I. LANGUAGE AND COMPOSITION:

The special object of the course in Language and Composition is to prepare the teacher to train his pupils to speak and to write good English as a fixed unconscious habit.

Oral and written composition: Their relation; the purposes served by each; correction of common errors of speech and of written answers; discussion and exemplification of topics suitable for each Form, with reasons for selection; suggestions as to sources of material; methods of dealing with oral and written compositions; how, and when to teach the sentence, the paragraph and the use of capitals, punctuation marks, etc.; story telling and its value; letter writing; informal grammar taken up in language lessons.

The following special methodology of teaching English to French-speaking pupils of Form I should be discussed and illustrated.

As far as possible, the Natural, or Direct, method shall be followed. This consists in establishing the same direct association between experience and expression as exists in the use of the mother tongue—in associating in the mind the impression or idea directly with the English word, and, in the process, the eye, ear, and voice should be used successively—showing, expressing, and having the pupils repeat. The object is to give the pupils the command of the language as a means of oral and written self-expression.

Oral and concrete work exclusively at first, followed by reading from the blackboard or charts and by writing, when pupils have acquired a certain ability in the correct pronunciation of common words, phrases, and sentences. Later, the written exercises should embrace transcription, paraphrasing, spelling from dictation, and the composition of short sentences.

If the natural method is properly applied, the use of the mother-tongue will not often be required to teach English. When, however, it is required to clear up any difficulty or to avoid a loss of time, its use should be confined to explanations which are absolutely necessary.

The first step in the use of the natural method is to teach a certain number of names of objects which are found in the school or at home, and which are familiar to the pupils. This step should be followed by the teaching of some simple descriptive words, colours, qualities, dimensions, position; also the names of persons, and of the most common action-words. At this stage the teacher must use the objects themselves or their pictures, perform the actions, and have the pupils perform them. Connecting words are taught systematically through simple language lessons. To teach complex and abstract ideas, the teacher uses gestures, context, examples, comparison, and translation, when needed.

The general directions and communications, such as "stand up," "sit down," "go," "come," etc., are picked up without much difficulty. Numbers, names of the days, months and seasons, the usual forms of greeting, etc., should be taught incidentally. (See Sec. 32, Primary Reading Manual.)

Nursery Rhymes and Memory Gems being of great value as a means of acquiring a good pronunciation and of developing the sense of rhythm should be taught from the very beginning.

The pupil should understand clearly the meaning of everything he says, and he should never be asked to write or memorize anything that he does not understand clearly, and cannot say correctly.

(See Primary Reading Manual, page 47 and following pages.)

NOTE.—The classes in the First and Second courses in the methodology of teaching English to French-speaking pupils, might, for the present session, be taken together; and, for the class work two hours might be taken from the time allotted to Language and Composition in Reg. 8 above, with four additional hours from the time available under Reg. 8 above.
II. Reading:

The special object of the course in Reading is to prepare the teacher to train his pupils to get the writer's thought and feelings (intelligent reading), and to communicate them to the listener so that he may appreciate them (intelligible reading).

The course embraces the following topics:

- The two stages of reading, primary and advanced; how to start a class of beginners; the sentence, word, phonic, and combination methods; the planning of lessons for each Form; common faults on the part of both pupil and teacher and how to correct them; criticism by teachers and pupils; the use of supplementary readers and supplementary reading.

III. Spelling:

The special object of the course in Spelling is to prepare the teacher to secure accuracy in the mechanism of written word expression.

The course embraces the following topics:

- The importance and value of spelling to the pupil; relation to phonics; aural and visual types; when to be introduced; difficulties and how to overcome them; transcription and dictation; rewriting; grouping of words; testing and checking; devices for correction.

IV. Literature:

The special object of the course in Literature is to prepare the teacher to create in his pupils a taste for good literature.

The course embraces the following topics:

- An investigation of the previous reading of the teachers-in-training; qualities of literature most appeal to children of different ages; scope and purpose of literature in each Form; illustrated by taking up a poetry and a prose selection from each reader; the place and value of memory work; the use of the dictionary; supplementary reading; lesson procedure; preparation by teacher and by pupils; special value of memorization and of oral reading after preliminary study.

V. Grammar:

The special object of the course in Grammar is to prepare the teacher to secure precision of expression on the part of the pupils, to train them in habits of logical analysis, and to give them a basis for self-criticism in language.

The course embraces the following topics:

- The relation of language and composition to grammar; the reasons for postponing the introduction of formal grammar to Form IV; the order of developing the subject; the inductive-deductive method illustrated by a few lessons on various topics; method of dealing with analysis and parsing in the class; rules of syntax, their value, treatment of false syntax.

VI. History:

The special object of the course in History is to prepare the teacher to train pupils to adapt human experiences to present situations. In the elementary stages, the chief objects at first are to arouse an interest in historical studies and to give pupils a knowledge of their civil rights and duties; and at a later stage to enable them to appreciate the logical sequence of events.

The course embraces the following topics:

- What makes an event important; work suitable for the primary, intermediate, and advanced stages; the value of biography and local history, illustrations; the use of the text-books, and of the reader for Form III; devices in teaching for each Form; supplementary reading; our Flag, its history and significance.

VII. Geography:

The special object of the course in Geography is to prepare the teacher to extend the pupil's knowledge of the earth and its relation to life thereon.

The course embraces the following topics:

- The scope of geography; the observational phase of geography; use of globe and maps; local Geography; dependence of commerce and local industries upon soil, climate, and other physical conditions; study of a continent, of a country; how to use and to draw maps; work outside of school; excursions; how to use the Geography Reader for Form III.

VIII. Nature Study:

The special object of the course in Nature Study is to broaden and deepen the teacher's interests and sympathies, and, through him, those of his pupils.

The course embraces the following topics:

- The relation of nature study to agriculture; special characteristics of a typical nature study lesson; a general discussion of the work suitable for each form and each season; uses and limitations of books, pictures, collections, etc.

Note.—Owing to the time of the year and the shortness of the session, not much can be done in this subject, but the pupils should be directed how to use the Manual in carrying on the work of the different Forms. A few excursions should be made on Saturday afternoons.

IX. Arithmetic:

The special object of the course in Arithmetic is to enable the teacher-in-training to give instruction in the various arithmetical processes, so as to ensure accuracy and rapidity. The chief attention should be paid to the work of Forms I, II, and III.
The course embraces the following topics:

Importance of arithmetic to the life of every child; an outline of the work for each Form; method of each important operation; drill problems, oral and supplementary work; particular attention to primary number combinations, the four rules, fractions, tables; importance of accuracy, neatness, and speed, and how to attain them; the use of the prescribed apparatus.

X. Writing:

The object of the course in Writing is to enable the teacher-in-training to write rapidly and legibly, and to make him familiar with the best means of securing the most satisfactory results with the pupils.

The course embraces the following topics:

Penholding; position at desk; position of paper; various movement exercises; formation of the small and capital letters and the figures; practice on paper and on the black-board; importance of good writing in all school exercises.

Note.—Owing to the shortness of the session, not much more can be done in class in this subject than to direct the teacher-in-training how to carry on his own studies and the pupils' work in the different Forms.

XI. Art Work:

The special object of the course in Art is to give the teacher-in-training such a knowledge of the subject, such a training in his aesthetic nature, and such facility in the use of Art as a means of expression as will enable him to develop like tastes and powers in his pupils.

The course embraces the following topics:

Common objects; grouping of objects, grasses, flowers, trees, and simple landscapes; illustration of games, stories, etc.; black-board drawing; map drawing. All work should be freehand.

The course is to be taken up with pencil and colours, and the materials used by the teacher-in-training should be confined to those possible to the pupils of an ordinary school, as follows:

1. Paint box, containing blue, red, yellow, and black, 25 cents.
2. Drawing pencil "R" or "BB," according to make, 10 cents.
3. Soft charcoal, a box containing 50 sticks, 15 cents.
4. Coloured crayons (crayograph or crayola); a box, 10 cents.

The foregoing outfit may be obtained from The Geo. M. Hendry Co., Toronto.

Note.—Owing to the shortness of the session, not much more can be done in class in this subject than to direct the teacher-in-training how to carry on his own studies and the pupils' work in the different Forms.

XII. Music:

When practicable the study of Rote Songs adapted to the lower Forms should be taken up as often as possible from the Tonic-Solfa or Staff Notation. This should begin with the simpler elements of time and tune, proceeding to more advanced grades.

Note.—The Educational Music Course (The Canada Publishing Co., Toronto) may be referred to.

XIII. Physiology and Hygiene:

The object of the course in Physiology and Hygiene is to provide the teacher-in-training with the knowledge requisite for the maintenance of the health of himself and his pupils, and to qualify him for supervising the sanitary conditions of the school and its surroundings.

The course includes general instructions for the detection of the existence of common communicable diseases, to enable the teacher to comply with the provisions of The Public Health Act; modes of preventing the spread of these diseases.

The rest of the course should consist of general directions, how to take up the subject in Forms I and II, and how to use the Reader for Form III, and the text-book for Form IV.

XIV. Physical Training:

The special object of the course in Physical Culture is to enable the teacher-in-training to make proper provision for the physical training of his pupils by means of a series of graded exercises to be used as recreation in class-room in intervals between classes and of recreative gymnastics or gymnastic games, and indoor and outdoor games.

As much practice as possible should be given in the foregoing, at the Summer Model School. Part of the recess period might, with advantage, be used for this purpose. Each teacher is required to put into practice in his school the course detailed in The Syllabus of Physical Exercises for Public Elementary Schools.
SYLLABUS OF SECOND YEAR'S COURSE

The Second Course of Study for the Summer Model Schools outlined below includes a review of the subjects of the First Course.

1. PRELIMINARY COURSE OF STUDY

Before taking up the Second Year's Course at a Summer Model School, the student will be expected, after the present session, to have made himself familiar with the text-books prescribed for the First Course as well as with the following:

McMurray: The Method of the Recitation.
Gordy: Psychology.
Tilley: Methods of Teaching.
Millar: School Management.

The Manuals of Method, as soon as published, will take the place of Tilley's Methods of Teaching.

The following course should be used as a guide by the teacher in preparing himself for the Second Summer course, when, as far as practicable, the details under each head will be taken up in class.

2. EDUCATIONAL PRINCIPLES AND GENERAL METHODOLOGY

Aim of Education: Examination of the chief current definitions of Education; relation of aim to procedure in Education;

Laws underlying the Process of Teaching: The relation of analysis to synthesis, of induction to deduction; purpose of methods of instruction.

The Plan of the Recitation: Adjustment to the needs of the capacities of the pupils; relation of previous work; examination of the "five formal steps" of the Herbartians.

Questions and Answers: Use of questioning in the development of the individual and general notions; right and wrong methods of questioning; examination of the so-called Socratic method; answers; qualities of a good answer; treatment of faulty answers; mistakes in dealing with answers; illustrations, their office and value.

Instincts and Interests: The place of natural tendencies in the development of a normal life; study of some of the more significant of the child's instincts and interests; methods of eliminating, strengthening, or modifying instincts and interests.

Habit and Association: Nature of habit; relation of habit to instinct; conditions of the formation of habits; the laws of habit applied to school studies, especially to those involving the acquisition of skill such as writing, reading, manual training, art, etc.; the place of habit in character formation; nature of association; conditions of association; relation of association to habit; how to form permanent associations.

Apperception: Nature of apperception; necessity for making subjects taught meaningful; the process of interpreting the new in terms of the old applied to school studies; significance of the maxim, "Proceed from the known to the related unknown."

Attention: Nature of attention as a process; conditions of attention; relation of attention to habit and association; interest in its relation to attention; voluntary and non-voluntary attention distinguished; attention in young children and in adults compared; methods of securing and retaining attention; obstacles to attention.

Retention: Conditions of retention; the relation of retention and apperception; the factors in efficient recall; functions of the drill lesson and of the review lesson; methods of conducting drill and review.

Individual and General Notions: How they are distinguished from each other; how individual notions should be approached and presented; how to proceed from individual to general notions; the value of types in the development of general notions; how general notions should be applied.

Impression and Expression: Their interdependence; importance of this interdependence as the basis for the constructive side of school work; its bearing upon the development of character.

3. SCHOOL ORGANIZATION AND MANAGEMENT

The Teacher: Natural qualifications of a good teacher; importance of scholarship, training, experience, professional studies, wide culture, Teachers' Associations; of good magazines, professional and cultural, etc.; the teacher's relations with the principal, the inspector, trustees, parents; civic and social duties; personal power and influence in the school and the community; daily preparation for teaching; correcting written exercises; care of health.

Classification: The value of school organization; evils of over-classification; promotions, when and how made.

The Daily Programme: Principles involved in the construction of a time-table; seat work; individual black-board work; the question of fatigue; typical time-tables for ungraded schools; school records.

Written Examinations: Good effects; bad effects; school results that cannot be tested by examinations; how to set examination papers; reading and valuing the answers; examinations as related to promotions.

School-room Routine: Chief varieties of mechanizing routine, their advantages and disadvantages; appointment of monitors.

Desirable School Habits: Punctuality; neatness in person and in work; accuracy; promptness; quietness; industry; obedience; the relation of the preceding to moral training.
School Incentives: Kinds and office; effects on character, on school work, on health.

Order and Discipline: What is meant by good order; the chief elements of governing power; faults and how to avoid them; co-operation of school and home; punishment, ends and necessity, right conditions, characteristics of judicious punishment, injudicious punishment, the discipline of consequences.

Physical Education: Relations of physical and intellectual development; importance of change of work; value of plays and games; organized and unorganized play; the teacher on the playground; physical exercise within the school.

The Kindergarten: Its essential principles; relation to the school system as a whole.

Note.—For information as to the necessary details of School Accommodations and Equipment, the teacher-in-training is referred to Circular 33.

4. SCHOOL LAW AND REGULATIONS

The Ontario School Law and Regulations in so far as they deal with the duties and obligations of teachers and pupils. The following should be emphasized—

The importance of signing the name correctly and the Christian name in full and of specifying, in the case of females, whether Miss or Mrs.

The necessity of making all agreements clear and conclusive. These should be contracts as provided by the statute. Substituting for the contract an agreement made orally or by correspondence often leads to misunderstanding and difficulty. (P. S. Act, section 85 and form of agreement.)

Note.—Every school register contains two copies of a form of agreement, one for the teacher and one for the Board. Additional copies may be obtained on application to the Department.

Duties of teachers and inspectors. The payments of the Grants and other matters directly affecting the teacher, trustees, and school. (P. S. Act, sections 6, 7, 8, 9, 82, 84, 87, 99, 116; and Instructions 12, 13 and 14.)

Regulations of the Public Schools.

The calling and conducting of school meetings and the consideration of matters incidental thereto, such as the duties of auditors, appeal to Inspectors, etc. (P. S. Act, sections 49-54, 59, 63, 66, 72, 75-81.)

Non-resident pupils and the charging of fees. (P. S. Act, sections 70 and 71.)

Penalties and prohibitions regarding the buying and selling of textbooks and school supplies and the use of unauthorized books and pamphlets. (Department of Education Act, section 28; P. S. Act, section 112, and the Text-book Regulations, Circular 14.)

The Ontario Public Health Act and regulations, so far as they pertain to teachers, pupils, and the school.

5. SPECIAL METHODOLOGY

The directions already given for carrying on the First course apply to the Second course as well.

I. LANGUAGE AND COMPOSITION

Oral and Written Composition: Their relation; how habits of speaking and writing correctly are formed; the effect of the teacher's example upon the pupil's language; importance of libraries for supplementary reading; influences opposed to good usage; incidental work in language training; expression as a stage in the development of every lesson; necessity for special exercises in oral and written composition.

Methods in Oral and Written Composition: Methods of encouraging the pupil's free natural expression and of extending his vocabulary through oral exercises; principles of composition; methods of oral work; the dangers connected therewith and the means of avoiding them; value of formal linguistic exercises; the relation of a knowledge of grammatical rules to the development of correct forms in speech; method of correcting common errors; relative value of pupil's own language and of special exercises in false syntax as material for criticism; the principles to be kept in view in conducting exercises in written composition; supervision and aid during writing; value of topical outlines; the place of home-work in written compositions; methods of correcting compositions; value of re-writing.

Materials for Written and Oral Composition: Principles governing choice of topics; gathering, selecting, and arranging material; class answers as material for oral composition; importance of framing questions that will require answers of considerable length; the reproduction of fairy and folk stories, fables, poems, biographies; relative value of reading and telling stories; transition from reproduction to originality; descriptions of personal experiences, real and imaginary; pictures suggestive of stories; school scenes; autobiographical and family history; developing themes from minor incidents; themes connected with school studies, general themes; letter writing, with special attention to form and style; invitations and replies thereto; bills, receipts, promissory notes, etc.

Note.—For the outline of the course in the methodology of teaching English to French-speaking pupils, see First course, p. 13.

II. READING

The Scope of Reading: The importance of training in reading and in the principles of vocal expression to the pupil's ordinary speech and general culture; the limitations of the pupil's ability to interpret words; his previous preparation.
Methods in Reading: The word, sentence, phonic, and combination methods; devices for securing rapid word recognition and for fixing attention on the thought, as well as upon the word forms in the earlier stages; means of securing natural expressive reading; the place and limitations of imitation reading; common faults in the reading of both pupil and teacher and how to correct them; criticism by teacher and by pupils. Change in purpose and methods of reading as determined by the development of the pupil's experience and powers; methods of developing in pupils the habit of reading for thought and pleasure; reading as a means of creating and fostering a taste for good literature.

Forms of Reading: The function and value of silent reading, sight reading, dramatic reading, elocution, declamation.

III. SPELLING

Scope of Spelling: Its correlation with other subjects; causes of the difficulties experienced by pupils in learning to spell; causes of incorrect spelling.

Methods in Spelling: Necessity for teaching, not merely testing spelling; phonetic exercises and word-building in relation to spelling; syllabication; the place of transcription and dictation; methods of checking and correcting errors; value of re-writing; prevention versus correction; the character of drill and review exercises in spelling; methods of varying the spelling recitation; value of rules in spelling.

Materials for Spelling: Principles of selection of material for spelling; grouping of words for the purpose of spelling; incidental spelling; uses of the dictionary and of the spelling-book.

IV. LITERATURE

Selection of Subject-matter for Literature Lessons: Qualities of literature that appeal to children of different ages; basis of selection of material for different grades; lists of suitable nursery rhymes, fairy tales, fables, nature stories, etc., adapted to children of lower grades and of works for pupils in the highest grades; complete wholes versus extracts.

Methods in Literature: The application of the general principles of method to the teaching of literature; methods of dealing with primary literature; comparison of values of reading and telling; method in supplementary reading contrasted with that in exact study; the importance and method of memorizing selections; the value of oral reading in the interpretation and appreciation of literature; the importance of the teacher's own ability to read well.

Lesson Procedure: Preparation of the pupils; necessity for preparing a suitable mood for lesson; how far the author's biography has a place here; preliminary reading of the selection; the main thought of the lesson grasped in a more or less indefinite way through a reading of it; the analysis of a selection into its wider thought-elements and the analysis of these again into their elements; the place of explanation of words and phrases; the use of the dictionary; the relation of the subordinate thoughts to the unity of the whole, the main thought of the selection as made definite by the analysis; the oral reading of the selection by pupils after study; the value of oral and written reproduction and of memorization; suitable seat work.

Examinations in Literature: Difficulties of examining in literature; specimen examination questions.

Teacher's Preparation: Special importance of teacher's own qualifications; private reading-courses for teachers; suggestions for their future reading.

School Library: Principles to be kept in view in selecting works for the school library; methods of making use of school library; means of securing the co-operation of the home in the pupil's reading.

V. GRAMMAR

Meaning of grammar; the relation of grammar to speech, correlation with other subjects; reasons for deferring the formal study till Form IV.

The sentence as the starting point; basal value of function; order and method of teaching the parts of speech; principles of classification as applied to grammar; inflection, use and value of our remaining inflections; rules of syntax, their value; use of grammatical terminology; definitions, their value; how to be obtained, how to be applied; analysis and parsing, aim and value of each; value of diagrams; oral and written exercises; treatment of false syntax.

VI. HISTORY

The Scope of History: The correlation of history with other subjects, especially geography; the special value of Canadian and of British history; the proper perspective in the development of the subjects; parts enlarged in the academic review; what makes an event important.

Methods in History: The recitation, its form and purposes. Oral teaching and black-board work by teacher, and of written exercises at seat and at black-board by pupils; oral and written work; the use of pictures, maps, etc.; of the readers and the text-books; relation of method to the personality of the teacher and his knowledge of the subject; special importance of preparation of lesson by teacher owing to mass of detail; errors to be avoided.
The selection and arrangement of material suitable for different grades, the place and purpose of local history and the history of the aborigines and pioneers.

Biography: The natural attractiveness of biography; the relation of biography in history; the use of a study of biography in the development of character; selection of suitable biographies for pupils of different grades, as the lives of explorers, navigators, and soldiers for primary grades of statesmen, poets, scientists, etc., as representing more complex conditions, for pupils of higher grades.

Epochs: Their relation to biography; systematic chronological study of history and its value and dangers; the causal sequence of events.

Civics: Ends to be kept in view in teaching civics; consideration of work to be undertaken in civics; study of civic institutions as appearing in their lowest forms among primitive peoples; the beginnings of governments, of courts, of school systems, of factories, of means of transportation, etc.; study of present forms of civic institutions.

Supplementary Material: The use of mythology, ballads, orations, epics, legends, tales of chivalry, narrative poems, and historical novels; character of history readers and of supplementary works for the different grades, significance and value of our Flag.

VII. GEOGRAPHY

The Scope of Geography: Its relations to other subjects, especially to Nature Study, History, and Elementary Science.

The review of the course should lay special emphasis on the study of the earth's surface and the changes wrought thereon by the various agencies, rock formation and soils, distribution of mineral products, plant and animal life, the earth's relation to other heavenly bodies, weather and climate, man's relation to the rest of the world, and commercial and political geography.

Methods in Geography: The order of development of the subject in rural and urban schools; the use of maps, globes, pictures, blackboard drawings, natural objects, specimens of products, stereoscopic views; sand-table; scrap-book; modelling, map drawing, scales and projections; weather observations and records, simple experiments in explanation of natural phenomena; excursions in connection with the observations in local geography; the use of the reference library, books of travel, geography readers, etc., common mistakes in teaching geography and means of avoiding them; special importance of the preparation of the lesson by teacher owing to the mass of details.

VIII. NATURE STUDY

The Character and Scope of Nature Study: Its relation to formal science; its correlation with other subjects.

Material for Nature Study: Conditions determining the choice of material for nature study lessons for pupils of different grades, and for varying conditions in rural and urban schools; uses and limitations of books, pictures, models, collections, etc.; supplementary materials such as stories, literature, etc.

Methods in Nature Study: Nature Study as a method; special characteristics of a typical nature study lesson; directions for conducting school excursions; the study of special typical topics dealing with materials of nature study and illustrating methods of presentation in all grades of public schools.

IX. ARITHMETIC

The Scope of Arithmetic: Its relation to the other subjects of the Curriculum; importance of its practical aspects as related to the lives of the pupils; the various steps involved in the development of the number idea; the unit, its nature and use; the necessity for standard units; number a ratio.

Methods in Arithmetic: Analysis and synthesis, induction and deduction, compared, illustrated, and applied; graphic methods; use of concrete material in making clear new processes and in verifying and interpreting operations performed; the use of text-books and of prescribed apparatus; the importance of intuition, and devices for securing success; necessary rules and special combinations; the existence, place, and treatment of oral arithmetic; the value of problems; the essentials of proper solutions; solutions by full analysis, and by performing operations only; "unitary" method and method of direct measurement; grading of problems; interest in problems for which the pupils themselves furnish the material; black-board work; drill and examination work in arithmetic; checking written work in the class-rooms.

The various arithmetical operations and their applications, with special stress upon the requirements of teachers engaged in rural Public School work. The work to the end of Form III should receive most attention, even if this entails the omission of some of the topics under applied arithmetic. The course should include the following:

Counting; measuring with standard units; numbers 1 to 10, from 10 to 20, etc.; number pictures; notation and numeration; addition-tables, exercises, devices; subtraction by decomposition, by equal additions, and by complimentary additions; multiplication, relation to other operations,
tables, exercises, factors; division, short and long, factoring, cancellation, division by factors; measures and multiples.

Fractions: How and when to be introduced, different interpretations, notations, rules for operations deduced and applied; decimal fractions, correspondence of methods of numeration, notation, and operations with those of integers; recurring decimals.

Applied Arithmetic: Percentage, trade discount, commission, insurance, taxes, interest, discount; stocks, exchange; tables of weights and measures; the metric system; mensuration, including the areas of rectangles, triangles, parallelograms, and circles, and the volume of rectangular solids, cylinders, prisms, cones, and spheres; square root.

X. Writing

Methods in Writing: Penholding; position at the desk; position of the paper; the proper formation of the small and capital letters and the figures; various movement exercises; practice on paper and on the black-board.

Use of headlines and copybooks; use of blank paper; its ruling; value of transcription, dictation and composition in writing; use of the black-board to teach the correct form of each letter singly and in combination; how general and individual faults are corrected; the formation of a characteristic hand; how to deal with pupils having some physical disability.

XI. Art Work

The Scope of Art: Art as a mode of expression and a means of aesthetic culture; its correlation with other subjects in the school course.

How to Use the Various Mediums: Charcoal, ink, coloured crayons, water colours, and pencil.

Plant Study, including the drawing of plants or any parts of plants in ink, charcoal, crayon, or pencil mass, and in water colours, pencil outline, and pencil values.

Tree Study in any medium.

Landscape in ink, water colours, and pencil.

Object Drawing: Simple familiar objects in charcoal, ink, or pencil mass.

The drawing of common spherical, cylindrical, and rectangular objects illustrating the principles of freehand perspective—pencil.

Illustration: Games, occupations, nursery rhymes, and stories chiefly in charcoal, pencil, and ink.

Pose Drawing: Ink mass, pencil outline, pencil values, and water colours.

Black-board Drawing: White and coloured crayons and charcoal.

Colour Harmonies and Neutral Values: Water colours.

Design: The repetition of simple units to form borders and surface patterns and the application of design to constructed objects so as to show good spacing.

A.II. Music

Tune:

Practice in singing, from the Tonic-Solfa modulator, or the Staff, the simpler intervals of the Major Scale, in any key.

Time:

Practice in singing simple rhythmic exercises in two, three, four, and six pulse measure, containing continued tones and easy divisions of the beat.

Voice Culture:

Practice in breath control and exercises calculated to promote correct habits of voice production in speaking and singing.

Songs:

The study of Hote Songs adapted to the lower forms of Public Schools.

The study of songs learned by note, from the Tonic-Solfa, or Staff notation. This should commence with the simpler elements of time and tune, and proceed to more advanced grades, as may be found practicable in the time available for this purpose.

XIII. Physiology and Hygiene

General instructions for the detection of the existence of common communicable diseases, to enable the teacher to comply with the provisions of The Public Health Act; modes of preventing spread of these diseases.

Personal Hygiene.

Care of teeth, skin, eyes and ears; relation of exercise to health; effects of alcohol and tobacco.

First aid in such cases as fainting, suffocation, drowning, hemorrhage, fractures and dislocations, venous stings, poisoning, frost-bites, sunstroke and heat stroke, burns; bandaging.

Ottawa, Jan. 24th, 1914.

Sir;

With reference to school matters at Rama reserve which I was asked to take up I beg to report as follows.

At a council meeting of the band, held on the 22nd inst I informed the Indians that the department would not support their request for a night school for adults to be conducted by Mr. Elias. They were given to understand that they could not make use of or have access to any of the day school material or building. The council had passed a resolution asking that Elias be paid $25 monthly from the band funds. I informed them that the Department would not allow this payment to be made from band funds. They were further informed that if they were determined to carry on the night school scheme that they would have to support it from their own pockets and furnish what supplies they needed from the same source.

Mr. Elias being present, I informed him in presence of the band that the department would stand for no interference with the work of the day school; that he was not residing on the reserve with the consent of the Superintendent General and that he was therefore a trespasser and would be so dealt with in accordance with Sec. 34 of the Indian Act if he interfered in any way with the day school, its pupils or its teachers. He was also informed that he should not accept as pupils any children under 16 years of age.
The meeting was somewhat stormy, the Indians and Mr. Elias not taking very kindly to the plainness of my remarks. I fully expected this, however, as these Indians are inclined to unrest and agitation. I made the matter as plain as possible to them in order that there might be no room for excuse in case of further trouble from this source. I hope that the talk I gave them may have the desired effect but am not certain that it will. The Indian Agent was present at the meeting.

I have the honor to be,

Your obedient servant,

Inspector.

RAMA RESERVE SCHOOL FAIR.

The First in the County of Ontario.

Mr. R. A. McLennan, Inspector of Public Schools for the North District of Ontario, has been present at the school fair last Thursday, on the Rama Reserve in this county, the result of which is a cause for congratulation, to show how much interest the pupils and teachers in charge of the school, who take so deep an interest in the welfare of their school and district.

The first rural school fair, proper, is being held this year by the reserve school on the Rama Indian Reserve, near Grimsby. The unique feature of the fair was something unique in its way, the garden exhibits. There were no gardens at the school, and the manual exhibits were the only ones on display in the school room. The result was a most interesting display of the work of Miss McFaul and Miss Waite, who have worked so faithfully to make it a success.

The beautiful new two-room school, which belongs to the teachers, is situated on the Rama Reserve on a piece of land which is very fertile, and requires only cultivation to make it productive. To grow vegetables requires very little land, and cultivation has been undertaken successfully by the pupils of the school. It is to be hoped that the school can continue the experiment and show possibilities of the land and that, when they become independent farmers, the land will be productive fields of grain and vegetables.

The fair is the object of the school and the parents of the pupils.

Of course the older men are benevolent towards the children, and there is no doubt that they would resort to lessons from two lady teachers, Miss McFaul and Miss Waite. Miss McFaul and Miss Waite are quite able to demonstrate their knowledge of gardening and farming than are to be found on the reserve.

Professor S. M. McCready, of the Ontario Agricultural College, Guelph, was present, and was very much pleased to address the pupils at the afternoon session, in the afternoon on the school grounds, and also gave a talk on the subject of the concert in the Council Chambers. The people came in large numbers to hear Prof. McCready's glowing account of what the pupils could do by growing good corn and vegetables under his supervision.

Madam,

I beg to inform you that the Department is in receipt of a report from Mr. Hutchinson, Public School Inspector, on the Rama Indian Day School, in which he states that the tone of the school could not be better and that the teachers are doing good work and the school garden has awakened a real interest. The Inspector also states that he attended the school fair held on the afternoon of October 15th, last, and that the hand work, i.e., the sewing, art work, box making, etc., was surprisingly good and the garden produce was far superior to anything on the reserve.

Dear Sir,

I am writing to ask for help in the work here. Last month, I threw open my school room for the youths and men of the reserve to use as a reading room or anything suitable that may develop from that. The pastor supervises. So far, it has been a success. This month I arranged a different programme and it has been accepted. It is as follows:

1st Monday in the month — Prayer Meeting.
2nd — Agricultural Discussions.
3rd — Literary-Miscellaneous (Debates)
4th — Social — Reading — Games.
5th — Open for suggestions.

I have promised to take up the Agriculture with them, and some appear really interested. When I was at Guelph this year, I understood Prof. McCready to say that the Dept. supplied seed free to Indians who were progressive.
enough to experiment with it - and follow instructions. If I have rightly understood him, may I know what help I can expect for them?

Miss Mc Bain intends taking Domestic Science with the girls and women on the Reserve, in the New Year. I hope they turn up as well as the men, then we shall feel well repaid for our efforts.

Wishing you the complements of the season -

Yours truly,

(Elmo) Ruth Waite

RAMA RESERVE

On Friday afternoon, the pupils of the Rama Indian school assembled in the Senior schoolroom to witness an interesting presentation. Among those present, also the Rev. John Nelson, Mr. N. M. Nelson, Mr. C. W. Myers. The pupils sang in their own language and afterwards in English some patriotic songs. Appropriate addresses were made by the teacher, the Agent and Mr. David Simcoe. The pupils then read their reports, and then came the most interesting part of the afternoon, when the Chief presented Miss Evans, Director of the Princess Mary Gift Book. The book had been forwarded from the Department of Indian Affairs as a gift of the Hon. W. J. Roche. The Chief and Mr. Simcoe addressed the pupils in their own language, the meeting closed with "God Save the King," the beneficent patron of the minister. October 23, 1915

Sir,

I beg to report as follows:

To above number and date. The Inspector Mr. McFadden report as to Rama Reserve way school attendance being unsatisfactory. The Indians go North to be guides and the families also, they sell their fancy work to the tourists. This year the return of the Indians' families was about last week in September, which was later than other years, and when Inspector Mr. McFadden was here he found this state of affairs which was no fault of any neglect of duty of the officials, as we were all at our post. The children were away with their parents. The teachers reported in their quarterly report this cause of the small attendance.

The Inspector laid down the law at the afternoon meeting as to school regulations; the School Officer was on the alert when the families returned, and our attendance at school is now satisfactory.

I am writing to get an opportunity to make an impression as to school neglect, which I have not as yet got the chance.

J.B. McLean Esq.

Sam your obedient servant,
Acting Deputy Superintendent of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.

Sir,

I beg to acknowledge the receipt of your telegram of the 11th instant from St. Thomas as follows: "Am not familiar with procedure under section nine in case of obstruction. Please mail instructions or wire name of lawyer care Orillia hotel. Will have to lay over Sunday so that there would be time for letter."

In reply I beg to say that the parent of the children in question should be notified of the intention of the agent to commit them to an industrial or boarding school. If no objection is made within four days after such notice by the parent, you should lay an information before the agent setting forth that the children are neglected and stating whether objection has been made. If no objection has been made the agent should issue his warrant to the constable to search for and take the children to an industrial or boarding school. If objection has been made the agent should first summon the parent to appear and show how the children are being educated and that the parent is a fit person to care for and educate the children. If the parent fails to establish this to the satisfaction of the agent the latter should

H. C. Parker, Esq.,
Care of Orillia Hotel,
Orillia,
Ont.
should issue his warrant to the constable to search for and take the children to the school as aforesaid.

I may say that possibly the notice already given to the parent in this case as to the intention to commit may be sufficient without further notice. The agent will have to be the judge as to this.

With respect to obstruction as referred to in your telegram, I have to say that if anyone obstructs the constable the latter should warn the offender that he or she is liable to prosecution under the Criminal Code for such an offence. It is thought however, that any obstruction that the parent in this case may be able to offer should not deter the officer from executing the warrant. If however, such obstruction is offered as to prevent the officer executing the warrant an information should be laid against the offender before a magistrate under Sec.169 of the Criminal Code.

I am inclosing some forms that may be helpful.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean

The Women's Institute met on Tuesday evening, May 16th, and held the first annual meeting. The officers were re-elected, and are as follows: President, Miss McIlvain; Vice-President, Mrs. Smith; Secretary-Treasurer, Miss Walter. Mrs. Hopkins was the guest lecturer, and Mrs. T. Williams were appointed Directors; and the following were elected: Mrs. Hopkins, Mrs. Stinson, Mrs. W. Smith, Mrs. H. Smith, Mrs. Shilling, and Mrs. E. Shilling. The seats sent up by Mr. Putnam for the garden centre were accepted. Mrs. R. Kentell, Mrs. W. Snache, Mrs. R. Shilling, and Mrs. Kentell. The meeting was more encouraging than any we have had. Probably the members are beginning to realize the importance of which the Institute stands—Home and Country.

SOLDIERS have never been in Rama a weekend quite like this, in all its history. Soldiers on parade in Rama. The Nightingale Band met the five o'clock train on Saturday night, and the soldiers marched to the Council Hall, where they were given a hearty welcome. The Hall was crowded to overflowing for the concert in the evening. Needless to say, the Band played as well as ever. On Sunday afternoon, the Band had gathered about two o'clock, and marched through the part of the village, returning in plenty of time for the afternoon service. Many officers were present from Orillia. In fact there were so many visitors from Orillia and Long Branch that the church would not hold the crowd, and consequently the service was held in the open air. It was a glorious day. All nature seemed to welcome the event—the promise of a new Honour Roll. The day will never be forgotten. It is a day that will live in the hearts of Rama. The Rev. John Nelson opened the service, and the Band played the hymns. The Rev. Mr. Anderson, in a few appropriate words, expressed his high opinion of the Rama women, and their response to the call of King and Country. He then called upon Captain the Rev. P. W. Anderson, who read the "Acton Service" booklets, which the Rev. Mr. Walter had prepared. The Rev. Mr. Anderson in a few appropriate words, congratulated the soldiers on their splendid record, and the call of the Empire in this terrible struggle for right, honour and liberty. He briefly referred to the admiration on the booklet cover—"Quit you like men." Mr. Nelson then called upon Captain Miller, who spoke before the audience. Rama owes him a deep debt of gratitude for the beautiful home he has given to the community. He even told the audience that he would make it better than any she had previously made, and the work is certainly exquisite. He spoke of the patriotism of the mothers and girls of Rama, for so readily giving their sons and daughters, and growing the Empire. He spoke of the pleasure it gave him to see the ladies of Rama presenting a new honour roll to replace the small one which will not hold all the names of those who have died. The boys had done splendidly and the whole community should be proud of them. Many white communities, where in many instances, the women were holding back the men, but Rama took up the franchise, and the Indians, who are now citizens, too. The women could thus excuse themselves from active service, have nobly risen to the occasion and responded to the call of the Empire. Again they were congratulated. Captains Miller of the local battalion, and Lieut. Gladstone of the 17th, each made a brief speech, commending the ladies for the manner in which they fulfilled their duties. They were good, efficient helpers. The ladies then thanked Captain Miller for the Honour Roll, and also thanked the ladies of Rama for their presence. His speech was very brief. He seemed specially solicitous for the comfort of the ladies. The Rev. Mr. Franklin made a patriotic speech, referring to the sacrifices made by the forefathers took a part. What they did then, they can and will do again. He ended by saying "Long live the Indian."

The service concluded with the National Anthem. In the evening there was a special service held in the church, which had been very prettily decorated for the occasion of the day. Private William Martell preached, chiefly in Indian. He made a speech, saying that they must rise to the great battle of conquering themselves. They must rise to the battle and not fall to do their duty to their King and Country. No one could listen to him without being impressed by his earnestness. He is a God-fearing man. Mr. Samson Ingersoll also addressed the audience for a few minutes.

Sir,

Do you think the Department would raise my salary from $500 to $550 a year? When I first went to the Rama School, I understood that my salary was equal with that of Miss McCain, and that our positions were of equal value. It is only during the last few months that I have discovered the inferiority of my own financially. I did not feel justified in asking for an increase of salary before on account of my ill health, not knowing whether I would be strong enough to continue the work. Now however I think I am justified. I have had a good vacation on the Atlantic coast in Rhode Island and Massachusetts and am quite strong again.

I have taught the Senior pupils in the Rama Indian School for 2½ years and have materially increased the curriculum. I introduced Agriculture and sewing the month the school opened, and have taken them weekly since.

Lessons in
Elementary Hygiene and Physiology are given regularly. Last year I added Domestic Science to the curriculum and the girls take this subject on Friday afternoon. Two remain after school hours on Friday, and apply the instructions given. When war broke out, I taught the girls to knit, and the few I had, knitted $10 worth of yarn for the Red Cross. The money was the proceeds of a concert they gave for the purpose.

The Fall Fair in 1914 was due to my efforts and I am hoping we will have another this year.

I am not in the habit of retailing all I do. This is exceptional and I hope I have not wearied you.

Yours faithfully,

Ruth Waite

It is 3 years and 1 month since I came to Rama. During that time, I have studied the Rama Indian at close quarters, and drawn my own conclusions about them. I may be right and I may be wrong, but I have thought for a long time that the social conditions of the people, housing, morals etc., are in a deplorable condition. What to do for the best, is a huge problem. It is certainly best to make them help themselves wherever possible. My chief hope of salvation is with the children. Yet when they leave school, they seem to lose all ambition. There is no occupation for them—no training. I feel as if I would like them under my supervision until they were 18, yet with present conditions here, it would be impracticable. We would need an Indian High School. I have 2 very nice, good little girls, who could take Entrance next year, but for many reasons, High School would be out of the question. The girls enjoy their lessons in cookery, but accommodation is so limited here. I can only take all together with a demonstration lesson.
I often think an oil stove in the school room would be a valuable asset. Then the pupils who remain for the mid-day meal could "warm up" their lunch. It would be more convenient also for the cooking lessons. I never encourage the pupils to remain at school during the noon hour. I think if they are suitably dressed, and the weather fairly good, it does them more good to get the exercise and fresh air to and from home.

I often think organized games would considerably help these children, physically and morally. There is such a spirit of good comradeship developed in outdoor sports. The boys play football. Each season they subscribe towards a ball. The girls have no desire to subscribe for balls. They do not know how to play and do not show any inclination for organized play. In England, we had outdoor sports as part of the curriculum. Every child had to take part, swimming for girls and boys, rounders & tennis (girls), football and cricket (boys). None were excepted unless physically unfit. I would like to have organized games as part of my school curriculum (one a week). I consider it physical and moral training.

If you would grant us a football, (for captain ball) and baseball equipment.
I might commence the scheme.
I have taught my pupils, Captain Ball and Overhead Ball, but they have not caught the spirit of play yet—except the boys. They enjoy their football after school hours in the fall of the year.

Another thing that distresses me, is the fact that young motherless girls, with only old people responsible for them, just run wild. If those girls had only had a course in Domestic Science they might have made their homes decent and taken pride in the care of them. A 6 months course, living in the school house, under the supervision of the teachers, might help, if we could make it practicable.

Just one more suggestion. Can we not form a branch of the Society for Prevention of Cruelty to Animals? The half starved dogs, badly housed animals, and frequently ill treated also birds—are sometimes a distressing sight. I do all I can to get the children to love and care for the animals.

I hope I have not wearied you—but I have wanted to say this and more, for a long time. They are only suggestions, but we may evolve something worth while from them.

The Secretary
